item.title: Personal//Independent Genetics
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
I have tried very hard to keep my personal life separate from my business. I think its more professional. Unfortunately, I feel as though I need to explain myself. I haven't blogged in a while, I haven’t updated facebook, I haven’t returned voicemails and I've been horrible about answering emails this week. 


 
Me & My cousin/office assistant Abby, Rachel & Kate [Who model regularly for us] and sister and stylist Caitlin. 

You see, this is a family business. My sister and cousin work with me. My brother helps with odds and ends in the office. Even Gabriela and Martha are sisters. We work with families and our team is as close as one.  My family is unlike any other family I have seen. I know I am a bit bias but please know that I am not saying this is a good thing or a bad thing, It is just a fact. We are large, I can go into a grocery store, cook out or bank and I'm either related to someone or someone knows someone I'm related too. Growing up, my mom and a few of her sisters all lived in the same condo complex. There was an open door policy so whenever we needed ketchup we would run down stairs. Whenever a high school crush upset me all of my aunts knew before I could reach my diary. We fight, just like everyone else. The difference? We make up immediately. We love passionately, We forgive quickly. We are tight night, we are as large as an army and I promise you we are very different than any other family you have met. 
 
                                                        My cousins, aunt and brother. Doing the chicken dance. 

My grandmother was born in 1924, a time that wasn't great for women. She stepped outside of tradition and married a man who didn't belong to the Catholic Church. In an era that marriage was a woman’s life goal, my grandmother had a wedding in a catholic church rectory room, with very few witnesses and wasn't allowed to wear white. She married a man who shortly after the wedding day was taken off to war. 

Can you imagine? In a time when a woman's pivotal life goal was to marry, she had a small ceremony and wasn’t even allowed to wear white. Women didn't work, didn't go to college. They married. They married well, they had an elaborate event, dressed up and invited everyone. My grandmother sacrificed these things to marry a man she loved. Which sounds simple to us now but I understand at that time it wasn't easy. She loved him hard. 

Jean, my grandmother, had 9 children. The amazing part, only one of them was a boy. Yes, that is right. My mother has 7 sisters. Jean was pregnant 7.5 years of her life. That is insane. You have to think of the 40's and 50's when she was raising her house full of daughters. Women were raised to be housewives, they didn't have opinions, they were to marry and raise children. Women were paid less, respected less and seen as weak. Some how in my grandmother's graceful way she raised 8 beautiful and independent women. She taught them to require respect from your significant other, she taught them the value of education. In a time where women professionally married I believe more than half of her daughters went to college. If they wanted a family that was fine, but they had options and they needed to take care of themselves. The difficulty of doing this in a time when women were arm candy to their husbands entraps me. These are qualities that have been passed down through my mother to me.
 
                                                                                          Caitlin [my sister], my grandmother and I

Please allow me to interject here. My grandmother was not your typical grandmother. She wasn’t soft, she wasn’t cuddly or going to coddle you. We never made sugar cookies or played dress up. I’m not even sure what children do with their grandparents. I am sure though, I didn’t do it with her. She was thin, picky and had a room called the East Wing we were never and still never allowed to walk into. It was a room saved for when the pope or Elvis came to visit. Despite all of that my grandmother was fiercely intelligent and opinionated. I can remember her waving her hands and “talking loudly” at me when I decided to drop out of college. Even more so I remember the look on her face when she patted my hand and told me that she had been bragging to her bridge friends about her granddaughters business. She wasn’t soft and cuddly, but she loved us and she had a way about her that you didn’t mind that she hated baking.

My grandparents also had a very balanced marriage. During the same era, men rarely respected women or their marriage vows. My grandfather saw my grandmother as an equal, they were in their marriage together, raising a family. Together. They were married 65 beautiful, frustrating, rewarding years. Unfortunately the last 10 years of that marriage my grandfather was diagnosed and suffered from dementia. If you aren't familiar with the disease go watch the movie The Notebook. It keeps your body healthy but steals your memory and your mind. My grandmother took daily care of my grandfather; bathing him, dressing him and feeding him until he passed away. Their marriage is something to be respected. I know it wasn't easy for them, but they loved each other. Their journey was long and rough but they held hands while they walked through it. 
 
                                                                                         My only grandparents, Rex and Jean.

My grandmother stayed in her house and lived alone after my grandfather passed. I saw her at least once a week. We talked books, had lunch. She stayed active. She played bridge, had the ladies over. She was still so independent. That is until about a year ago. She started to complain about a pain in her back and legs. We had no idea what it was. We took her to a physical therapist. After a month or so of intense pain and asking her to stretch daily they did a blood test. The details are fuzzy for me, but we discovered she had bone cancer. Think about this. We had an 87 year old woman stretching and cancer was taking over her body. How could we have not seen this? It turned out she had a cancerous tumor on her spinal cord, it broke a few bones.

Trips through chemo, back to the hospital because her vitals were low, arguments over medication, which doctor to see, should she be in the hospital? Second sets of chemo, cement in her back and more chemo. It has been a rough year. About a week ago, they brought hospice in. My grandmother's calcium levels were too high and there was no fighting it. They sent her home to rest and to die in the comfort of her own home. It was sad, disturbing and yet somehow beautiful the way my family and I stepped it during this bridge in my grandmothers life. We cared for her just as she had cared for her children when they came into this world.

My grandmother passed away this week. This strong, independent woman is finally liberated from a body that failed her. It was a heart wrench thing to watch, but she was well cared for and loved through it. She is now able to rest. No matter your faith, I trust that she is finally enjoying time with her husband and isn’t feeling any pain. My family and I have been planning her services and they will be going on this weekend. I am telling you all of this because I want to explain my absence and I needed to share how intensely impactful my grandmother was on so many people’s lives. 

I wanted to thank all of you for being so understanding and patient as I get through this with my family. I would like to give a very special thank you to one of our brides who is getting married tomorrow. Mary-Beth has been one of the sweetest brides I have worked with. She has had a trial with my sister Caitlin for her hair and her wedding is Saturday as is my grandmother’s funeral. I’m sure you can imagine the predicament. I called to explain and to work out a plan with her and she has so kindly agreed to allow Caitlin to do her hair at some god-awful time in the morning on Saturday so that my sister could make it to the funeral. I have had to adjust artists, time frames and I assume I have added stress to her the week of her wedding and she has been so gracious to us. I am very thankful for both Mary-Beth and her planner, Emilie Hilsenrath from Events and Wedding Bliss for working with us through such a difficult time. Thank you all for your patience, I will be back in the saddle and cleaning up this mess of a desk and email inbox on Sunday. 

Xo, 

Alison
 
                                                                                             My amazing grandparents

item.title: Personal//The Long & Short Of It
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
Since we've launched our fab new site I've gotten quite a few sweet emails. If you've throughly looked through our site. [I'll forgive you this time] You might have noticed a few photos from my wedding on my personal bio page. I've had a few ladies ask to see additional photos of my hair from my wedding. HOW FLATTERING?! 

Seriously. I love you all for telling me how fabulous I looked on my wedding. Not weird at all. I did get asked to see photos so I started thinking, I should explain the power of extensions. You see, I've been struggling with growing my hair out. Its been a forever battle. My hair was only this long when my wedding rolled around: 

 

Please do not judge me, I hadn't done anything to it the morning of the wedding. At all. That and we were getting ready in a high school dressing room. [That's Jen doing my makeup!] As you can see though, my hair is like barely a bob. 


 
This most unflattering photo shows Gabriela and my sister Caitlin clipping in my extensions from the back. Why, yes. I am writing a letter to my soon to be husband in the middle of all of this. Which goes to show that no matter how much you plan things get hectic. 

I used the Jessica Simpson Clip in Pieces. Please note though: They wouldn't curl! I should've purchased untreated human hair clip in pieces. They made it work but it would've worked better if I used my brain. 


 
Once they were clipped in, Gabriela and Martha started styling. I know, I felt like a celebrity. I was seconds away from yelling for green m&m's. Please see below.



 
Move over Mariah Carey. 


 
Hours into our reception

Here is the finished product after a few hours. My hair was literally just long enough in the back to clip up, everything you see is basically extensions. The awesome part about this? I didn't get a trial for my hair. Crazy, no? I just trusted the girls to know what they are doing. I said, "I want something classic, low, secure and soft" 

I like what they did. If you are thinking about extension pieces we love using them. We don't charge anything to put your pieces in and style them. I think they can make all the difference in the world for your wedding day do. Hope this is helpful. Don't worry loves, I'll post wedding photos soon. 

Xo, 
Alison

item.title: Published//Fresh Squeezed Weddings Sarah Khan Event Styling Charm City Wed
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
Soo.. I'm bring this post thing back a bit because we really have been everywhere and unless you like us on our facebook page. [WHICH YOU SHOULD] You would have no idea just how famous my girls are in the wedding world. They are famous. So to prove that fact, oh and to brag a little about my extensive talent in cropping screen shots we bring you this post! 



One of our beautiful brides and her very cool wedding with our friends at Softbox Media was picked up over at Vie D'Amour, which you can see here. 

 



This pretty sweet styled shoot we did with Stacey Vaeth Photography was picked up by Fresh Squezzed Weddings. I've never seen this blog, but my god it is addicting. You can see that here. 
 



The very awesome Sarah Khan just launched her new site and you can see some of our sweet south asian work on her portfolio page. She handmade this custom floral jewlery, which is to die for. You can see it here.
 



One of our bride's Lauren's photos from her beautiful wedding at the Antrim 1844 was featured on our friends Flutterphoto's blog. You can see that over here. 
 



We had the pleasure of not only becoming one of the beauty vendors on the new Baltimore based blog, Charm City Wed, we also did the hair and makeup for Serena and Rochelle's headshots! Make sure you stop by their blog to see us here. 
 



Another of our smoking brides was blogged by her photographer Jessica Schmitt.You can see some of her magic over here. 
 



Now this is kind of fun. We did this really intense styled shoot with all these crazy vendors and our friends Softbox Media. It was picked up in like 3 different places. There is so much eye candy with this shoot that you should see it. You can find some of the pictures, here on Borrowed Blue, Here on Capital Romance and alsohere on Storyboard Wedding. 
 
 
 



We had a really lovely traditional DC wedding featured on The East Coast Bride. She had traces of pink and it was so classic. The photographers for this wedding were pretty cool too, An Endless Pursuit. You can see that here. 
 


I just had to post a few photos with my mad-crazy screenshot skills of Becky. She was so beautiful! Loved it.
 




Obviously we enjoy Styled Shoots ATON. So we did another one. Which was put together by Emilie Hilsenrath by events and weddings bliss and was shot by Sweet Tea Photography by Lisa Marie. Peachy, huh? You can see some of that here. 
 




We also have been hitting the boudoir world pretty hard these days. We did some work recently with Softbox media and you can see some of this magic here. 
 


Lastly, I was recently interviewed by Karen Buck of Wedding411 about different hair and makeup topics. They put together two fabulous podcasts. One of which is on our blog here. The other is in the line up and coming to you soon! Here is a still from our interview! Scoot on over here to check more out. 
 



See I didn't lie, is this not like the longest blog post ever? We have been EVERYWHERE. Crazy, huh?
Xo, 
Alison

item.title: Personal//Sunrise Coffee & PJ's
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
I woke up the morning of the wedding with the sun. I was so so excited. Somehow, the serious amount of wine I had drank the night before didn't effect me at all. I wanted to throw open the windows on this beautiful February morning and yell. Today, I will marry him. The man I was made to marry. My dress was in its bag, my glitter heels, veil and necklace were ready to go. I could have put the dress on at 6 am. But, it was a little too early for that. I knew it was too early, I was in a room with some of my family and I'd just have to force myself back to sleep.


I rolled over and my mom was wide awake too. I nudged her, "let's get coffee" We snuck out of our hotel room leaving my little brother and his friend on the pull out couch snoring. I didn't even glance in the mirror. We stepped on the elevator while the whole hotel was sleeping. I remember looking over at her and chuckling, her hair was a mess, she had on my little brothers flip flops and we hadn't even changed out of our pjs. I probably looked worse. We strolled by the front desk and I'm sure they chuckled too. 



My mom and I spent the next hour sipping coffee and talking. I can't honestly remember what we talked about. All I remember is that we talked about everything and anything. It was an amazing start to my wedding day. Pjs, coffee, bed head -just my mom and I. Growing up as one of five children you kind of get stuck in the shuffle. As a middle child you get grouped in a lot of the time. I've spent time alone with my mom before but never like this. We had fought, argued and cried with this wedding planning. Anything that I chose she wanted the opposite. Anything she suggested I hated. We didn't see eye to eye with this wedding at all. It was the most amazing, magical 6 months but also the most tedious and frustrating. Sitting in that little dinner across the table from my mom in all her bed-headed glory, I could tell she was happy and excited for me. All of that frustration and arguing was behind us. I've never felt as connect to my mom as I did during our coffee sun rise talk. Her calm confidence that this was the perfect step for me made me calm and confident. I knew that this was right. I just knew it.

item.title: Real Wedding//Tammy's Beach Wedding at Herrington On The Bay
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
Just a few months ago we had the pleasure of meeting Tammy and all her lady loves. 
We had a trial and a few months later we drove out to Herrington on the Bay to help make them all fabulous. 
The girls have been to Harrington before, but I hadn't. This was my first experience. 
They have the cutest little cottages right on the water. 
I want to live there. 
That's not weird, right? 

Tammy was really sweet. 
At her trial she had her sister, mom and all the little ones running around.
We tried a few different styles, tweaked things. 
Until we finally found what we loved. 


When we arrived the morning of her wedding, all her ladies were in their matching "bridesmaids" shirts,
 lounging around munching on snacks. Talking about how they knew each other.  
Super cool. super laid back. 
Super fabulous.
I loved how much family was surrounding Tammy on her wedding day. 
Her sister helped into her dress, 
her mom dressed her step-daughter. 
It was really touching. 
You could just see how many people cared for her this day. 


Side note: 
Tammy's hair was a real challenge for me. She wanted a style that I had some difficulty with.
I left her trial feeling like a total train wreck. 
We tried quite a few styles, all of which were nice but not quite there.
All that struggle helped me grow.
I went home, I practiced. I studied and I practiced some more. 
Her hair turned out to be 
one of my proudest achievements. 


Please enjoy these photos of Tammy's Beach Inspired wedding. 
It was an amazing beautiful day for the two of them. 
We were so blessed to be a part of their morning!



Hair & Makeup: 
Katy & Alison 

 
 
Can we talk about how beautiful Tammy looks? 
Please, seriously fab.
-Don't worry, I burned that shirt and cardigan.- 
so bad.  
 
 
 
 
Omg, please look at his smile! 
So sweet. I love seeing photos of the groom looking at his bride. 
He looks like a kid in a candy shop. 
So sweet.  
 
 
 
I'd like to thank our friends over at Sapphire Style for sending us these gorgeous snap shots from Tammy's day. 
You can check out more of their work here!

 
Love it! 
Xo, 
Alison

item.title: Real Wedding//Sarah & Jon
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
Sarah emailed us a few months before her wedding. I had to do a double take. We had another wedding on the same day, 2 blocks away and the bride had the same last name. I asked her if she was related, which she replied.. no. So being the private-eye that I am, asked again. No. She reassured me. This was the beginning of our correspondence. I could not have started on a better foot. 


Sarah was laid back, classic and quite funny. I mean being kate-middleton beautiful doesn't hurt either. The morning of her wedding she was getting ready in one of the most beautiful hotels in Alexandria. The group of women she celebrated the morning with were equally relaxed. Normally when we walk into a hotel room there is a buzz. Sometimes it is on fire, electric with everyone jumping around. Music pumping, bridesmaids snapping pictures and the bride near tears. 


This morning was different. Sarah answered the door coffee cup in hand, in her flowy wrap dress "Good morning! A few of my friends will be here soon" Cool, calm and collected. She wanted a simple, classic look. A "I could have done this myself if I were really talented" kind of look. She just wanted to look beautiful for her husband, like her. Speaking of her husband, Jon.. anytime you asked Sarah a question about Jon her eyes lit up. Not in a teary eyed fairytale way, but in an I'm-completely-ready-to-spend-my-life-with-him way. If you ask me that is way better than fairytale tears. I wont walk you through all of this and talk the whole time, I'll just let you see for yourself. Complete happiness for a couple so meant to be together.  


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

I'd like to thank Sarah for letting us be a part of her morning. I hope you had the most memorable day. I'd also like to thank our friends over at flutterphoto you can find them here. We've worked with them before, and they take really awe inspiring pictures. Until next time!
xo, 
Alison

item.title: Personal//So Last Night......
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
So. Yeah, last night. I went to a little area industry party put on by the knot. Last year, although I was an advertiser; I apparently did not make the cut. Basically I wasn't invited, because in case you were curious.. you had to be invited. I know, fancy -right? Well nothing makes you feel like the smelly kid in class like not being invited to a party that everyone you know will be at.  Imagine my glee, I use the word glee because that is the only way to describe the way I shook my fists in joy when I got the invite. 


Finally! I get to rub elbows with those people the knot thinks are awesome! I'm in. etc. etc.. It was beautiful. I walked in and it was an enchanted forest! They gave you gift bags, there were cupcakes with glitter on them. Edible glitter. It was beautiful, classy, inspirational and just what I imagined. I realized something last night. I mean it was a beautiful party, but as looking around the room at the beautiful decor, I was holding my pink champagne with the rock candy stirrer, grinning like my life depended on it and pretending my feet didn't hurt -I realized something. It started to click with me that there are some people that I want to align my business with, my goals with and my friendship with and some that I don't. I know that may sound simple and kind of "a-duh?" moment as I like to call it, it actually clicked in a real life situation. I looked around the group I was standing in and I realized a few of the other vendors were in it for the wrong reasons. I realized, "I don't like what you stand for. You aren't doing this for the right reasons and you don't treat your staff very well" Point blank, "you're just not that nice." 


Which of course made me think more about, what do I stand for? Why do I do this? What is my purpose? Am I nice? [There is something about rock candy that makes me all philosophical. oh and yes, I'm nice.] I am still chewing on that, because I feel like the answers to these questions are not easy, simple ones. I do know this, I do this because I am passionate about women feeling beautiful, relaxed and pampered. I do this for that moment when the bride slips her veil on and her Mom sheds a tear. I get to be a part of that. Not many people get to have such amazing moments at work. I appreciate my artists, without them this wouldn't even be possible and I genuinely love what I do. This is why I do what I do and now I know I am conscious of the fact that I want to surround my self and my business with others who feel like I do.

item.title: Real Wedding//Caren at Milton Ridge
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
So a little while back, one of our lovely brides Caren got married. 
I got an email this morning from her Sister who is also getting married! 
How exciting!!! 
I know I'm a little overdue for a blog post but I thought, what perfect timing! 
Caren was married on a beautiful August afternoon in the most intimate setting, 
a lovely little place called Milton Ridge.
 There was even this perfect little house for us to get Caren and her sisters all ready in.
 I want to thank Andrew Morrell Photography for the sweet images of Caren getting all dolled up. 



It was really nice getting to know Caren and doing her hair, I hope she had an amazing, beautiful wedding day. 
She was so sweet, and not afraid of a little color!

item.title: Personal//Getting Back
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
This weekend, I had the chance to participate in a women's summit. I know, fancy sounding. Basically it was a small group of extremely talented wedding professionals. We opened up about our business and what our strengths and weaknesses were. We set goals and offered feedback. We were asked to bring our concerns with us to the table. When I sat back and thought about what I was having trouble with, only one thing came ringing like a bell. -How to enjoy life outside of work. 

You see, as a business owner work never stops. I'm checking my cell phone for emails at my family dinner. Not because I think I'm that important, but because I think "what will happen, if I don't get back to this email quick enough", "If I don't blog x number of days, we won't have readers" or "If I don't do this right now, they'll leave an unhappy review". The list goes on, as a business owner you live with a certain amount of fear. It makes it hard to relax and to focus on relaxing. Meaning not feeling guilty when I'm out getting my nails done instead of being strapped to my computer. 

That was my biggest concern. I brought it to the table and these fabulous women offered intense insight, advice and future reading material. Since then, I've been reevaluating my work life balance and learning to enjoy my life and my business. I'm saving myself from a future burn out and reviving why I started this business. I never thought I'd struggle to enjoy the small things but I'm getting there. Thank you to all the ladies I met this weekend. You are brilliant and offered me such wonderful feedback.

Xo, 
Alison

item.title: Personal//My Husband. The Dreamer.
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
When you talk with my husband you don't exactly walk away feeling warm and fuzzy, inspired or in tune with passionate zeal. He's a quiet, centered and simple man. In fact you'll think he's not listening when he is. Don't be fooled though, he is a collection of tangible, touchable dreams. He is the driving force in our house of jumping towards dreams. 

A little under two years ago, my husband looked at me, squinted his eyes, cocked his head and said "What do you have to lose?"

He paved the sidewalk for me to begin my journey into entrepreneurship. If I hadn't received a few uncomfortable loving shoves from him I wouldn't be standing here.  His encouragement has lead me to places I had never imagined. I have worked hard and tirelessly to get here, but I can't take all the credit. He has cajoled me, pushed me and even helped carry me when I needed it here. 

It is his turn now to be supported and tested. My husband has had this crazy dream for a while. I know it sounds insane but he has wanted to play Golf on a serious level since I've known him. Each day he walks between 18 and 36 holes with his clubs on his back, practicing the same chipping shot over and over and over again. I am in awe of him at times. I can't believe that passion for something could be so intense. It's his turn to start walking a path and I'm standing behind him giving him sweet little shoves now. 


 He is a dreamer, this one.

item.title: Personal//Picture Perfect
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
A week ago, I was sitting at my desk. Alone in the office, everyone had left. I rarely answer the phone myself these days and it was definitely after hours. I was writing out my to do list for the next day when one of the phones lit up. Without a thought I picked it up. It was a bride. She was asking about availability, pricing and trial runs. We chatted for a bit and I set up a consult for her and she asked "What do I have to do to have you hold my date?" I cautioned her to do a little comparison shopping, look around a little bit. I don't want my clients to run head first into our services. I want to make sure that we are what they really want. No pressure. In a very serious tone she replied "No, I know what I need. You guys are it." She proceeded to tell me a quick story that I've heard a hundred times over. Each time I hear it, a little part of my heart cracks.
Photo by Dani Leigh Photography
She had a friend who had gotten married last year. She found her makeup artist on craigslist. [Now, I caution here. I am sure there are plenty of talented people who advertise on craigslist. However they are grossly outnumbered by the amateur artists on craigslist] She found her makeup artist on craigslist for an affordable application. The morning of the wedding the artist showed up, did the makeup and went on her merry way. The bride cried about her makeup and before she walked down the aisle her bridesmaids scrambled to fix it. She told me that her friend wont even hang the photos from her wedding in their house. She is too upset about how she looked. The makeup looked nothing like her, a little too tan, she never wears eyeliner and you can see the difference from her face to her neck in color. You get the idea. I know that this sounds dramatic. Really, I appreciate that it does. Think about it. You are spending a lot of money on a beautiful venue, amazing photography. You've searched online for days and visited the dress shop multiple times for that perfect, very expensive dress. Why would someone want to pay for a half rate makeup application. This is how you look. This is personal. You are the bride, you are in every photo. If you don't like how you look, it is going to dramatically effect how you feel about your wedding photos. That is a fact. 
The beautiful Meredith on her wedding day.  Photo by Brian Tropiano Photography
I'm not sure why I am telling this story. If you are reading this blog, it is in hopes that you respect what we do and see the value in it. I think I am writing this because it upsets me every time I hear it. I am in the business of making someone look and feel beautiful. Confident. Radiant. That is my job and I take it very seriously. It really makes me feel for each individual that this happens to. I guess I am telling you this to help spread the word. If you know someone who is getting married, encourage them to go the professional route. It doesn't have to be with us. I would prefer a bride to go with our competition and be happy rather than go with a cheaper alternative and hate their photos. We aren't for everyone, but everyone that we are for, is well taken care of. We want you to feel beautiful. Confident & radiant. We want you to love your photos. The feelings you get when you look at them should have nothing to do with your makeup or hair. Your feelings should be exclusively about the memories from your wedding day. The excitement, the nervousness, the tears, the beauty, the kiss. Your love, not about your makeup. Go with a professional. xo. Alison
Our beautiful bride Katie & her dad before the ceremony.  Photo by my favorite Christine Barker Photography

item.title: Alison Harper Style//Oh My
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
I was at a bridal show a few months back. Chatting with brides, answering questions and doing demos. A bride approached my table and asked about pricing. I answered and she huffed back "oh, yeah right. I'll just go to a makeup counter at least I get to keep the product." OH MY. WHAT?! Be still my beating heart. I held my tongue but I realized that she could not be the only bride considering this option.  I decided to give this a try. See why someone would consider this as an option for their wedding. My friend Christine from Christine Barker Photography thought this would be an amazing opportunity to showcase the power of quality makeup in photographs. We decided to see what would happen when a bride uses this avenue to get her makeup done and then to see how well it photographs. To start this experiment, I called to set up an appointment at the MAC counter. They answered and told me that they don't make them. I could drop in and get it done that day. Perfect. Christine and I arrived when the store opened at 10a to get our makeup done. We were the only clients and we we're greeted by 5 makeup artists. We asked if we could get our makeup done for my wedding. I told them I needed to be back at the hotel for my ceremony at 2p. [ah, lies. I know.] The artist flipped through her book and told us they were all booked up. We were told to come back at 1p, they didn't have anyone to do it until then. Yeah, on my so called wedding day, I was blown off by 5 makeup artists. I was told that they don't take appointments, and apparently they do. Well I mean the other artists we're busy.. you know chatting with each other and drinking their starbucks.. Christine and I stepped outside to regroup. Well, that sure foiled our plan. We decided to try another makeup counter, just as any bride would have to do on her wedding day in this situation. We went into the bare essentials store. For a few dollars in product you can get your makeup done. Perfect! I assume that this is what a bride would do if MAC turned them away, right? Our artists were friendly and sanitary.. and trying to sell us product. I asked for a soft, simple and natural application. Although I did leave with a really pretty set of eye shadows and a mascara, our application took 3 hours. By the time we were finished, "my wedding" should have already started. I am not telling you this to sound like I am bashing anyone. The artists that did our makeup were really pleasant, the products I left with were nice and Christine and I had a good time. This is the perfect idea for a Saturday afternoon if you are looking for something fun to do with your girls. However. This is a really terrible idea for your wedding day. Besides the obvious reasons, I will let the images below speak for themselves. Christine and I returned to her studio and photographed my makeup with her professional equipment. I had one of our artists come and do professional airbrush on me as well. We photographed the makeup by an Alison Harper & Company artist under the same exact settings. These photos are not retouched. They are photographed under the same lights, same settings and with the same camera. See for yourself. I hope that this post will save at least one client from the hassle and heartache. Go with a professional when its so important. Save the counter for a fun afternoon with your girls, not your wedding day. xo, Alison
Makeup Counter
Alison Harper & Company
Makeup Counter
Alison Harper & Company
Makeup Counter
Alison Harper & Company

item.title: Personal//Silent Questions
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded: When we had talked about marriage, you used to get this look in your eyes. Your bright blue eyes would go a shade darker and the set of your mouth would be a little tighter. You never really said it, but your face gave you away. You were wondering if I really understood what forever was. If I was really ready to make that commitment. Since you never asked, I never answered. I had the answer. I knew it the moment I saw you. I knew it the moment you dropped onto your knee. I knew it when you asked. I made you wait and I stared into your eyes and I saw that color shift. I knew. I silently answered the silent question that you didn't ask. Yes, I meant forever.  We are going to fight, we are going to argue. This is life. It isn't going to be easy. We're going to have rough days, -hell, rough years. That doesn't matter. There are going to be speed bumps, tragedies and 7 year itches. That is going to happen. I'm going to go through all of this with you. If you think I'm going to let these things push through us, you are wrong. You and I will make it through this life together. So yes, you will be the hand I clutch when we welcome our future children into the world. You will be my Tuesday lasagna night dinner date, my sounding board. My support, my confidante. My cheerleader, my guardian, my advocate. You and I will do this forever. I will be yours and you will be mine. No one will ever have the part of my heart that you have. Xo, Alison

item.title: Personal//1 shade of gray, another shade of change.
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
My husband is many things. He's an amazing provider, a great golfer and very, very funny. He can handle almost anything I throw at him. Well he doesn't handle change well. You see, I come from a massive family. I was raised in complete chaos. On any given night, we could have dinner at home, down stairs at my aunts house, across our condo complex parking lot at 3 other aunts homes. That's just a simple example. I don't come from a home of regular structure. We could do our homework whenever, so long as it was finished when we got to class. My sister and I had our own bathroom and I one time kept a pet turtle in our shower for two weeks before my mom noticed. I was a cheerleader, played violin, volunteered, played softball and was in choir at one point. When you have a single mother with five children you learn to live in the chaos. I was raised by a village.
Thank you to Christine Barker Photography for these beautiful images!
My husband on the other hand was raised in a beautifully structured home. I have to give his mother credit for raising such an amazing man. I wasn't there, but I've been told about his childhood. They had dinner at dinner time, they did their homework and they played outside. They had baths before dinner and everything in their home had a place. My husband played baseball and golf. He had 4 siblings, who each had their own room and their own chores. He was raised by two very caring parents, in a home most of us hope to build for our families.
Thank you to Christine Barker Photography for these beautiful images!
The clash comes in when we moved in together. We had our share of challenges, I hate dishes, vacuuming and laundry. He hates not having clean cloths. [See what I mean?] We eventually found a balance. We have a great working relationship, he does some, I do some. It works perfect. Until, I wanted to decorate. We have been living in our condo for a little over a year. We're finally settled, comfortable and things have their place. That's when I started getting that itch. The itch that makes me want to pick up our whole home, flip it over and shake it. Knowing my husband, I decided to start small. We have a little entryway with a few stairs. The walls are white and get nicked up from carrying things into our home through that narrow passageway. I woke up yesterday and decided that wall needed to be grey. Yesterday, [excitedly] I rolled over "Hey, good morning. I'm going to paint that wall by our door grey." No questions, no room for argument. How did he respond? He rolled out of bed, got dressed and went golfing. He didn't say a word. Taking that as acceptance, I danced around lowes with color samples. Torn between "soft heather grey" and "satin silver fox," you would have thought I was repainting the Sistine Chapel. I ran home, taped everything up and slathered "London Fog" all over the walls. It was beautiful, and I did a pretty bang up job. My husband called me 3 times during my painting extravaganza. He wouldn't come home until I was done. I figured, I should make this a smooth transition for my husband. Otherwise he would die when I ask to redecorate the living room. I cleaned up, washed the brushes and put everything away. When he finally came in, he looked at the wall, looked at me and grunted. That was it. A simple grunt. That may not seem like much, but I know that grunt. His shoulders move just a little bit, his face tightens. That is his "It-looks-okay-I preferred-the-white-wall-but--its-not-worth-the-fight-I'll-let-her-have-it" look. I couldn't be happier. We are starting to learn to deal with each others challenges. By giving him the space to think things through and putting everything back to order before he gets home, he is comfortable. By doing those things, he has learned to allow me to do my thing. Unencumbered. The two of us, so different, are learning a balance. This balance will get us through the next 70 years. He and I are so, so different. I am learning how to push him into change gently and he is learning to adjust to my chaos. It is beautiful. It is balanced. I have one sparkling grey wall to showcase our beautiful, balance. Xo, Alison
Thank you to Christine Barker Photography for these beautiful images!

item.title: Personal//69 Years Ago
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
69 years ago my grandmother woke up and buttoned her brown checkered dress, slipped into her brown suede sling backs and wrapped her mink around her shoulders. She was headed to the alter to marry her love. Most women of her era lived for their wedding. Marriage was what they were raised for in the 30s and 40s. You were raised proper and then you married and made a home. A wedding was a womans coming of age, you had announcements in the paper, beautiful gifts and dresses. It was a very big ta-do in a womans life. You have to understand the sacrifice that my grandmother made when she married my grandfather in 1944. She didn't get to wear white, she didn't get to walk down the aisle and she didn't get to meet her groom at the altar. You see, my grandmother was Catholic. My grandfather, well he wasn't practicing anything. It was a pretty big scandal at the time. The church wouldn't allow my grandparents the right to a full catholic wedding with out two full Catholics. My grandmother wore brown, she married my grandfather in a quiet ceremony in the churches vestry. No bells, no whistles, no wedding announcements, no big party. My grandmother sacrificed these menial details because she was marrying the man she loved.
My grandparents on their wedding day; April 8, 1944.
Five days after this beautifully, simple ceremony my grandfather, Rex was shipped off to war. My grandmother, Jean wrote him a letter every single day for the entire year he was deployed. Every single day. He was living in a boat, traveling Europe and fighting for our country. He never received a single letter. It turns out that while he was away, his mail had never been forwarded. When he finally landed state side in New York, there was an entire trunk full of his brand new wife's love.
____________________________________________
My Grandmother Jean on her wedding day.
My grandparents had a beautiful marriage. In the 40's and 50's men had their role and women had another. Their marriage was different. They were a team, they were fighting battles together and were on the same side. My grandfather loved my grandmother. He truly, truly cherished her. He would help around the house leaving her little notes. He doted on my grandmother. On the other hand, my grandmother was a rock in their household. She was a loyal, polished and supportive wife. They raised 9 successful and brilliant children, traveled the world and deeply loved each other. My grandfather battled with different forms of cancer and dementia later in his life. My grandmother stood by his side during his 10 year fight. It was a long, long road. She insisted on keeping him at home, not in a nursing home. She cared for him all the way to the end of his life, holding his hand, feeding him and talking to him.  He died only a few short years ago. My grandmother honored his memory, remained faithful and remained his until she lost her life to bone cancer this past year.
My grandfathers military head shot circa 1942-1945ish.
My grandparents and the dedication they had to their marriage has left me with this rose colored view on love. They have given all of my cousins and I a fine example of how much work it takes to have such a solid and flourishing marriage. I can only hope that my husband and I will have half of the marriage that my grandparents had. Both of my grandparents are celebrating their first anniversary together in quite a few years. I miss them terribly but I know that they have a legacy and I am proud to be a part of that. Today, I want to acknowledge a love and a marriage that was strong, caring and truly beautiful. xo, Alison

item.title: Personal//Clean, Crisp, Masculine
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
I want morning and noon and nightfall with you. I want your tears, your smiles, your kisses.. the smell of your hair, the taste of your skin, the touch of your breath on my face. I want to see you in the final hours of my life.. to lie in your arms as I take my last breath. Hussein Nishah
Photo Credit: Michelle Lindsey Photography
In college I worked at the Deaf Independent Living Association and I went for my undergrad in Deaf Studies. Living so in depth in the deaf community you learn to stop listening. You rely on your other senses to compensate for your needs. Besides relying on feel and sight, I learned the power of smell. A scent can bring a memory rushing back through your brain just like the sound of someones voice. We all know the scents of our childhood, of autumn, the holidays and the beach. Each ripples through your brain and can bring you back there in seconds.
____________________________________
On our fourth date Jd invited me over to watch a movie. It was a bold move, we hadn't hung out in private yet. We sat awkwardly on his couch while I sung along to the opening song for the movie Juno. Once the movie started, we relaxed a little and he put his arm around the back of the couch. I sunk in and relaxed. At some point during the movie I leaned in and rested my head on his chest. That area. You know that area, between his shoulder and chest. The one part of him that I feel was carved out for me to curl up into. I remember the end of Juno, where Juno and Paulie were curled up in the hospital bed together crying. It was such a beautiful moment in the movie. I did that thing that girls do, I cleared my throat, touched my eyes. I tried to not let him see my eyes water. Don't we all want a guy to rush in at the end and love us right when we need it? I sunk into his shoulder and breathed deep. I will never forget that moment. It was a moment that I memorized his smell. It was a masculine clean smell. Like tide, fresh and crisp. I took it all in and commited it to memory. It was such a clear representation of him. He is a simple, organized, steady man. His scent was the same; clean, simple and steady. Later that night, when I went home I curled up in my own bed. Smiling deep into my pillow I noticed my own scent. Floral and light, busy and just a bit sweet. Such a perfect example of my individualism. I too committed to memory that scent. I memorized the melody of my own perfume. I wanted to be able to remember this happy feeling, getting to know someone new and falling for him.
Photo Credit: Dani Leigh Photography
 I didn't know then that this man would be my husband. I didn't know that we would plan and build a life together. When I was curled up on the couch with him on that fourth date, I didn't know that he would be the paulie to my juno. A few weeks ago, I traveled away on business. I was gone for almost an entire 2 weeks. When I finally came home I curled up on the couch with my cuddly schnauzer and relaxed. It was beautiful, 70 degree day and I had the windows open with a soft breeze. It was quiet and I was so happy to finally be home. I took a deep breath and realized that we have our own scent. As a family unit we have merged and have our own unique perfume. It was clean, and floral. Bright and crisp. It was a perfect harmony of the two of us. Unique to us and completely and totally made of the two of us as individuals. I committed that to memory too. When we have hard moments and tough challenges, I want to remember that day. That afternoon when I was so happy to be in our home. I couldn't wait to see him, to touch his face. To breath him in. xo, Alison

item.title: Alison Harper Style//Chic Wedding Inspiration
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
When I was planning my own wedding I scoured the web and checked in on some of my favorite local blogs. I love local blogs; United with Love, Charm City Wed, District Weddings, Capital Romance, Bayside Bride. Sometimes though, it is nice to see a little more variety and to gain a little more inspiration from across the wedding globe. After a following a few local blogs, I grew tired of mason jars and similar photographers. I wanted a little variety. Below are a few of my favorite inspirational wedding blogs. I hope this adds a little spice to your regular blog routine.

Alison

//Vogue Weddings//
We all know Vogue. Its classic, its fashion -its so chic.. and I rarely use that word. Their new wedding guide holds up to that same standard. Their weddings are timeless, elegant and very detail oriented. They feature celebrity weddings, real weddings and they are all organized by theme. Scoot on over there to see some of the prettiest flowers I have ever laid my eyes on.

Photo Credit: Vogue Wedding Guide

//Wed Luxe//
With the tag line "True Love, True Luxury", this blog is the foremost in luxury weddings. They post about all things wedding , from speakeasy wedding inspiration to packing for your honey moon. I love WedLuxe. They started as a beautiful, large scale Canadian wedding magazine and expanded into the bridal market. Almost 300 pages of the some of the best real wedding spreads.

Photo Credit: Wed Luxe

//Grace Ormonde Weddings//
You've seen the magazine. If you haven't you need to. Its beautiful, heavy and they feature some of the most over the top, beautiful weddings. I also love that they interview some of industry's leading vendors for honest, frank and well needed feedback. If you are looking for something that gives a little more than your regular blog routine scoot your pretty butt over there.

Photo Credit: Grace Ormonde Weddings

item.title: Alison Harper Style//The Perfect Red
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
Finding the perfect, illusive red is a pivotal day in a woman's life. Nothing can change your outlook like a pair of high heels and the perfect red lip. For most of us, its very difficult to find.
Photo Credit: Marcella Treybig Photography Makeup: Gabriela
Step 1//   Wash your face Remove all eye makeup, blush and liner. You'll need a completely fresh face to decide on the correct color. Step 2//    Decide your undertone There are three types of undertones: Cool (pink, red or bluish undertones) Warm (yellow or golden undertones) Neutral (a mix of warm and cool undertones) It may seem complicated to determine but it is actually quite simple. Study your clean face in a mirror. It is preferable to do this in natural light, so that your skin isn't tinted by artificial light. One test to help determine your undertone is to do the towel test. Pull your hair back and away from your face. Take a white towel or cloth and drape the cloth around your shoulders, neck and head. In comparison to the towel your skin will reflect its true undertone. If your face looks more yellow, you’re warm. If your skin has a blue tone you’re cool. Another basic guideline is; if you look good in silver, you probably have a cool undertone. If you look better in gold, then you're warm. If you look good in both, you’re probably neutral. Step 3//    Basic Rules Cool undertones, stick to a blue based red lipstick Warm undertones, stick to a red lipstick with a slight brown or orange component You should also pay attention to your skin shade as well as the undertone: Lighter: Corals or hints of orange Medium: slight brown or orange component Bronze: Cranberry or pink based colors Dark: Fig or cool based reds
Warm Undertones: 
Bobbi Brown Burnt Red; MAC Lustre Capricious; Laura Mercier Italian Summer
Cool Undertones
NARS Heat Wave; Dolce & Gabbana Ruby; Shiseido Valentine
Photo Credit: Adam Barnes Fine Art Photography

item.title: Alison Harper Style//Getting the most from your hair and make up trial
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
Photo Credit: Melissa Barrick Photography Makeup by Katy
A trial, consultation or practice run is a service that your hair or makeup artist perform as a dry run for your wedding day look. In most cases this will be done by the actual artist who will be performing your services the day of your wedding. With our team, our trials are performed at your location with the actual artists that are scheduled for your wedding day. We always suggest scheduling around 3 hours for your trial so that you can get the most out of your experience. We want to make sure you get the opportunity to find the perfect look for you and try out different styles. Make sure to adhere to these tips for getting the most out of your trial whether it is with us or another talented artist. Here's to you finding the perfect look for your wedding day!
Evan's wedding day makeup by Jen
Wear a white shirt// Have you ever noticed how most salons have bright, natural lighting? Your skin can change shade slightly based on what is surrounding it. If you have on a red shirt, your skin will have a slight pink tinge to it, etc. This makes your makeup artist's job a bit difficult in matching your natural skin color. Also, you'll be wearing white at your wedding, it may be best to see how your skin and the over all coloring will appear next to your dress. Have clean air dried hair// It is a common misconception to have 'one day dirty' hair. It is always preferable to work with clean hair. If your scalp is too oily, it may create difficulty creating the volume you may need. Also, when you flat iron, blow dry or curl your hair you are temporarily changing the structure. Once its been changed its difficult for us to get it to do anything else. It is best for your stylist to see your hair in its natural state to best understand what foundation they may be working with. Have pictures// This is one of the most important tips. Pictures of hair and makeup ideas help your artist to understand what you are trying to explain. There are endless shades of browns, pinks and reds. Your artist will need to know what you have in mind so that they can be create what you would like to see. I also suggest to my clients to bring photos of hair and makeup that they don't like, so I know what to steer away from. Remember that it is a practice run// Although this is a dry run of your wedding day, keep in mind that this may be the first time your artist may be working with your hair or skin. On the wedding day they will already know how your skin or hair reacts to different products or techniques; yielding better results. It is quite common for our clients to have adjustments and changes to their hair or makeup after the trial. Once they have worn the look, the feedback is appreciated. A good stylist or makeup artist should be able to adapt their service based on your feedback on the wedding day. Surround yourself with honest, loving feedback// A friend or family member's feedback is quite important. I urge you though, when planning your trial run; surround yourself with people who know your normal appearance. Occasionally your makeup artist may do a specific look that is just slightly off, you like it but you can't quite pin why it doesn't look like you. A familiar friend can usually spot the adjustment. Be careful though to surround yourself with people who are coming from a loving place. You will want honest, knowledgeable and constructive feedback. Have your accessories// Although your veil, earrings or even your teeka won't dramatically change the way your hair or makeup is done; it will help you with a complete visual of your look. This will help you to make decisions about specifics of your overall appearance. Most veils have similar application, so if you don't have it with you, don't panic. Your artist, should still know how to place or apply your accessory. Bring a camera// Your trial is a complete practice of your wedding day look. Most stylists in salon are not prepared with a camera during their work day. I would urge you not to rely on your stylist to take photos or to remember each nuance of your style. If you want to have the most accurate match, take photos after your salon visit and bring them with you on your wedding day. Any bridal specialist should be prepared with techniques to remember your look. Our artists will take notes and photos of your look as a reminder, but in most cases you wouldn't want to rely on this, in the event that the stylist in your salon is not prepared.
Interested in setting up a trial with one of our talented Alison Harper & Company beauty experts? Email us today at Info@AlisonHarperAndCompany.com. "Why wouldn't you want to look your best?"
Photo Credit: Eli Turner Studios Hair & Makeup by Gabriela

item.title: Personal//Love Notes
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
I woke this morning thinking of my grandparents. I'm not sure why. Just like anyone who has lost someone your mind occasionally wanders and you are stuck with that on your mind for the day. My grandparents were supportive, loving and  had a beautiful, sustainable relationship.
I've written about their love and its legacy a few times; here or here. As a loving unit they have given me a 'glass half full' view on love and marriage. They taught me that you can weather challenges and still find silver lining in a difficult situation. Through this they taught me that love isn't easy. You have to work for it. They stuck it out through good and bad, they learned each other and they made it work.My grandfather loved my grandmother. When we were going through their things after they had passed I found a few of these notes my grandmother had saved over the years. I keep them as a testament to true, hard earned love. I miss them both dearly, I hope to honor them with my marriage and keeping their legacy alive. Alison

item.title: Personal//Forever Flowers
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded: People are full of advice, most importantly when it comes to your wedding. "Make sure to pick a good photographer", "Plated, not buffet".. it goes on. I heard so, so much about my flowers. -I had my own thoughts about my flowers. In fact, I was down right weird about my flowers. In all of my mental, pro-environment, obsessive wedding thoughts; I realized I didn't feel good about shipping thousand of cut flowers in the middle of February. I just couldn't deal with the eviro-foot print. I realize how crazy I sound. I decided that I wanted to have a fake flower bouquet. Yes, I do also realize how tacky that sounds. I wanted a silk flower bouquet. The other minimal amount of flowers could be real. I was fine with that. I wanted to feel good about my contribution to a better, greener wedding. My perfect wedding, in my own bizarre way. I argued with my mom; my grandmother had opinions; pretty much anyone I told put their nose up. I fought the good fight for my flowers. Just as I am sure any bride does, with at least one part of their wedding with their parents. For some reason this one little thing I wanted really irked people. Guess what, I 'm glad that I fought for this little tiny part of my wedding that I cared about. Besides, I now have my flowers forever.. and I think they look pretty good in my grandmother's heirloom, Lenox vase in the middle of my dining room table. So pick what is important to you, no matter how absurd it may be. It is you and your husband's wedding and your memories. You wont regret it.

item.title: Personal//13 going on 30
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
Last Saturday night, when I was curling up with my adored Netflix account I was feeling nostalgic. Scrolling the romcom section, I stumbled upon an old favorite. 13 going on 30 -Jennifer Garner. In all its 90’s glory, chopsticks and fishnet chokers; it’s a story of a 13 year old girl who wishes she were an adult. In a very freaky-Friday moment she wakes up as a 30 year old magazine executive and realizes that it isn’t all it’s cracked up to be. In the end it’s all love and happy. It just makes you wish you could give hard learned, life advice to yourself.
Dear 13 year old me, Hi. It’s me. Yes, you. I just wanted to impart my new-found life experiences and drop a little knowledge on you. Here is my advice, Read as much as you can. When you get older, you won’t have time to sit down and read for a whole day on the porch in the sunshine like you do now. Absorb it, read everything. Don’t worry about missing anything. Reading can take you around the world and it will let you see things most people won’t ever see. Learn to talk less. As you get older you’ll learn the wisdom to listen more and talk less. Sometimes you don’t need to be heard, sometimes someone else needs you. When you talk less, you actually hear more.
Don’t fight with Mom. You don’t want to hear this but eventually you’ll be friends. You don’t know this now, but you are really –really similar. In fact your life will mirror hers. The things you might say now, will hurt her. Don’t, just don’t argue with her. She really does have your best interest at heart. Take yourself seriously. If you don’t then no one will. You hear about those kids that graduate from Princeton at 14? You can do that. Truly, if you decide that there is something you want to do, just do it. You really don’t understand this ability until you’re in your mid 20’s. You should know this earlier, you are completely capable. Learn to just be. One of the best things you’ll do is to learn to be alone. Unfortunately you don’t learn this until you’re in your mid 20’s. It’s a beautiful thing to watch the world. You learn a lot about yourself this way. Take a deep breath and watch the clouds pass by sometimes.
Everything will be fine. You are healthy, you have a loving husband and a beautiful family who will always help you back up. It will work out in the end. Just follow your path, trust that you are exactly where you are supposed to be right now. Just breath, Alison

item.title: Alison Harper Style//Bangs!
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
08/21/2013 7 Comments
In our last Industry tip post, we talked about how to pick the perfect haircut for your face shape.  If you need to figure out your face shape visit our last post here. Today, we're going to touch on whether you should take the plunge towards bangs or not. First things first, a few tips:
-NEVER cut your own bangs, in fact most salons offer free bang trims if you've gotten your hair cut with them. 9 times out of 10 if you attempt to cut your bangs, you'll end up with choppy or unevenness. -Your bangs will naturally lay better about a week after your cut. If you have anything important, say a wedding, get your hair cut at least a week before. -If you are really nervous about taking the jump, try out a add on piece. Any of these extension pieces can be just clipped in and snapped out. No commitment.
---------
Heavy Straight Bangs//  Oval, Triangular or Long Shaped Face
Head over to our last post to figure out your face shape. Straight, heavy bangs; often seen on Zooey Deschanel and rarely on the Taylor Swift can actually be worn by a few select fact shapes. Heart shaped or long face shapes are perfect for this blunt bang. By concealing the forehead and shortening the face it will help create a more chiseled jaw bone and present the illusion of an oval shaped face. People with oval shaped faces should avoid this style as it can sometimes appear overwhelming.
Soft Straight Bangs// Round, Square or Long Shaped Face 
The lighter, softer sister to the straight and heavy bang above quite versatile. Bangs in this shape can be rounded or shorter in the center allowing the bangs to conceal face roundness or to shorten a face shape. These bangs are often seen on Glee's Lea Michelle or Hunger Games star Jennifer Lawrence. Softer, lighter, straight bangs are also a great introduction into the heavy, straight bangs if you are considering them.
Long Side Swept Bang// Square Shaped Face
Long, wispier side bangs are the perfect accent for a square face shape. Soft bangs like those pictured on Sandra Bullock and Nichole Richie below, cut across the square dimension bringing the eyes across diagonally versus horizontally.  They help to soften the edges of this shape. Avoid short, sharp bangs as they can accentuate the squareness. Long side swept bangs can make a heart shaped or triangle shaped face appear longer.  Long, side swept bangs are also the perfect introduction into bangs. They grow out quickly and can be pinned back easily.
Soft, short side bangs// Heart, Oval or Triangular Shaped Face
The slightly, shorter and soft side swept bang is  a perfect accent to a heart or triangular shape. Luckily for the oval face shape these bangs don't overwhelm or shorten the face. These are easy to style but take a bit longer to grow out. Reese Witherspoon and the Olsen twins are perfect examples of soft, short, side swept bangs. Shorter hairstyles like the one Miley Cyrus is sporting are also flattering with their shorter fringe around the face.

item.title: Personal//Eye Contact
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
18 months ago, I sat in a white dress. Wringing my hands and counting the seconds until I could finally see you. I had been cooped up in that busy high school dressing room for far too long. Some one handed me a glass of champagne and I couldn't even drink it. I was so nervous. Not bad nervous, good nervous. I mean the nervous that still makes you want to throw up.. but good nervous none the less. With in the hour you were going to make me your wife. You were going to give me your last name and promise to keep me for the rest of your life.
We didn't really think about the logistics of it all, I was getting ready in the high school drama room attached to the stage. You had to walk through it to get out in front of our friends and family. It happened for a split second. You tried to keep your head down, all you had to do was make a quick left turn to go down the hall. You didn't. Just in that split second, you glanced up and found me. In that cheesy, dramatic, movie type of way; time stopped. We locked eyes. You gave me that little, tiny, brief smile. That one where just the right side of your lip goes up just a hint. Barely noticeable.
In that moment, things calmed. My hands stopped shaking, my nerves stopped dancing. Peace, just peace. I knew. I knew it was right. In that moment everything settled. We weren't supposed to see each other; 'its bad luck.' We've heard it all. This was out of our hands, God just dropped this little reassurance in my lap, this little gift. Telling me that I was exactly where I was supposed to be in that moment. We've never discussed this, our families thinking our first look was at the altar. This was just our little moment. When time stopped for just us.

item.title: Personal//Perfection
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
I was grabbing sushi with a good friend of mine, Christine when we shared stories, recent struggles and victories. I was talking about how frustrating it is to work so hard on something to not have it work out perfectly when she said to me"Perfection equals death" I laughed at her melodramatic sentiment for a second when she stopped me. 



"No really, have you ever had the perfect day? Once everything is perfect there is nothing left to strive for. When it has become perfect, there is no point to keep going."I've had this thought on my mind since our dinner. Perfection equals death. We are always busy trying to reach for perfect, but what happens when we finally get there? Replaying our conversation in my mind makes me a little more, okay with things not being completely perfect all the time.. I mean what else would I strive for if I reached it?

item.title: Alison Harper Style//Veils
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
Veils have a rich history, dating back to biblical times and having different meanings and requirements for different cultures. It symbolizes modesty, protection and religious affiliation. That and they are gorgeous. No matter the reasoning behind your choice, we want to help you to find the right style. Picking a dress has its own set of challenges. Finding the right fabric, cut and style for your body can pose some difficulty. When I found my perfect dress, I had an even more difficult time finding the right hair accessory. In my experience, I've noticed that most brides don't realize there is such variety with veils, nor do they know the correct vocabulary. To help you in your hair accessory search, we've put together this quick guide to different veil types. Here's a quick guide and a few examples.
Photo Credit: Wedding Fantasies
------
Cathedral Veil
This is the most dramatic veil, spanning over 3 and a half yards. This veil, usually worn with a dress that has a train will require someone to help lay it out before the big walk. This veil can be worn alone or with the blushed added [see below] Here is an example of the Cathedral Veil worn by our beautiful Alison Harper bride, Kelly.
Photo Credit: Deb Lindsey Photography
Lace Cap 
This style, worn recently by Kate Moss. (pictured below) is sometimes referred to as the Juliet Cap. The name was chosen from depictions of Shakespeare's Juliet was pictured wearing a similar lace cap. This veil was originally produced in the 16th century and became popular again in the 1920's and 1970's. This veil can be varying lengths and is fitted around the crown of the head.
Photo Credit: Pintrest
Chapel Veil
Slightly shorter than the Cathedral Veil, the Chapel Veil just reaches the floor. It can be worn with or without a blusher and is a perfect accent to a small train. With a veil like this you have to choose your hairstyle carefully, just like the cathedral veil it can be rather heavy. An example is our beautiful Ashley pictured below.
Photo Credit: Lauryn Galloway Photography
Pill Box Veil 
The pillbox hat goes as far back as ancient Rome. Made popular by the late Jackie Kennedy. This type of veil comes in quite a variety. The veil sits atop a small hat that is secured to the top of the head. Sometimes referred to as a fascinator this veil is quite popular across the pond.
Photo Credit: Green Wedding Shoes
Finger Tip Length Veil
The finger tip length veil reaches a bit longer than the elbow length grazing mid thigh. One of the most popular veil lengths, it can be beaded, laced or left simply. It can be worn with a blusher or without. The finger tip length is the most versatile as it can be worn underneath the hair style or just on top without weighing the hair down. The soft veil as pictured on Alison Harper & Company bride Kelly.
Photo Credit: Dani Leigh Photography
Blusher 
This veil piece is a nice additive to a few different veils. A blush is the piece of veil that comes across the face and covers down to the bride's bouquet. It can be added to the cathedral, chapel, finger tip, elbow, ballerina and sweep veils. It can be sewn onto these veils or on a separate comb. Please note this beautiful blusher worn by our bride Liz.
Photo Credit: Wendy Hickok Photography
Elbow Length Veil 
Another quite popular length of veil is the elbow length veil, which reaches to the elbow. Perfect for a light, airy accessory and doesn't overwhelm a tiny bride. It can also be worn with a blusher or as a simple single tier. As seen below a single tier elbow length blusher on our bride Natalie.
Photo Credit: Michelle Lindsay 
Mantilla Veil 
One of the most traditional style veils, the Mantilla, is fashioned after the lace scarfing that catholic women wore during holy days. It comes in a variety of colors, although most popular is white. It is usually lace edged and sits  on top of the hair in the crown area as pictured below. Although they vary in length, most commonly they reach about ankle length in the back.
Photo Credit: Style Me Pretty
Sweep/ Ballerina Veil 
Another popular veil length is the sweep length, also known as the ballerina length. This veil reaches between finger tip and chapel hitting about mid calf length. It is perfect for a taller bride or someone who doesn't want a veil that sits on the ground. It can be worn with a blusher as seen on our bride Alison below.
Photo Credit: Meredith Hanafi
Flyaway Veil
This veil is perfect for a bride wearing a dress with an intricately decorated back. This veil is just above shoulder length and is usually worn in one tier. Its light weight material makes for it to be easily worn in front or back of a hair style.
Photo Credit:  Posh Veils 
Bouffant Veil 
This veil, the bouffant is not for the shy. Its layered and full texture has recently made a major comeback on the wedding runways. It is usually worn short and its layers are pinned together to create body and to stay out of the face. It is stylish, chic and.. well, brave.
Photo Credit: Style Me Pretty 
Bird Cage Veil
Birdcage veils are generally short, fishnet style. Although most brides choose to wear them over their face, they can also be folded and worn over the back of the hairstyle. Most bird cage veils come with one to two small combs to help tuck it into the hair style. A secret hairstylist tip, you can spray the veil with a little corn starch spray, or hair spray if you're in a bind to get it into a specific shape. The birdcage veil worn across our bride Meghann looks stunning.
Photo Credit: L. Hewitt Photography
Side Veil 
Another brave veil choice is the side veil. It is usually work with a headband or small cap and a tie of tulle worn off to the side. Its bohemian style is light weight and is usually seen with intricate lace or beading. A striking veil choice for a bride with a simple dress.
Photo Credit: Style Me Pretty

item.title: Alison Harper Style//Getting the perfect brow wax
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
Unfortunately, we have all been there. In a quick hurry, you jet in to a new place for a clean up. You leave slightly irritated with really thin eyebrows. We've all been there. When leading up to a big event this can be a really big deal. Just like good skin, good eyebrows can help bring out your best features. Follow these simple tips to get the best eyebrow wax yet! xo
Please note! We always suggest planning any waxing or hair removal appointments at least 7-3 days before a big event. 
Photo Credit: Brooke Courtney Photography
Aesthetician not nail technician//
First of all, please know that this is not a knock to nail technicians education. Nail technicians are required to complete classes for 250 hours versus an aesthetic licence requires 600 hours. The focus of a nail technician's education is just that; nails. An aesthetician's education is focused around skin, skin care and hair removal. Any salon that offers facials, also offers skin care. The difference between the two is immeasurable, most nail salons you get a quick cookie cutter experience. A lot of times it is difficult to tell who is licensed and how clean the wax is. Where as in a salon setting you receive on average 15-20 minutes of your skin care therapists time. They have different options of wax, for different skin types, better lighting, better tools and they can take their time.
Do your research//
So you've made the decision to find an aesthetician for your waxing. Perfect! Now make sure to do the research needed. If you have any friends who have great brows ask around. Always make sure to check online reviews for a salon. They will give you the inside scoop on which employee is the better choice. Make sure to double check that your service provider is an actual aesthetician, occasionally if you are booking during a busy time they may schedule you with a nail technician or a hairstylist. Both are legally allowed to wax, but remember the idea is to get a specialist. Once you make your appointment, arrive 15 minutes early. They may need you to fill out a paper or two and you'll want to ensure that your skin care therapist has the entire window of time to dedicate to your eyebrows.
Let them grow//
This tip is a little challenging. Thankfully, the days of pencil thin brows are over. If you are just visiting an aesthetician for the first time, give it an extra week or two. It is best for your them to have a nice, full brow to shape. You will receive better results and your eye brows will grow in together, meaning your eyebrows wont be as unruly between sessions.
Photo Credit: Marcella Treybig Photography
Avoid certain medications//
Most people don't know this, but you should avoid certain medications almost 3 months prior to your waxing. Some of these medications can cause reactions, irritation and they can even cause your skin to peel off during a wax. Here is a basic list, but as always check with your doctor.
Adapalene, Alustra, Avage, Avita, Differin, Isotretinoin, Renova, Retin A, Tazarac, Tazarotene, Tretinoin
You will also want to pay attention to recent skin services you may have received. If you have had laser skin resurfacing, you'll need to wait 12 months before waxing. If you had a physician administered peel, you'll need to wait 24 months before waxing. Lastly, if you have a light chemical peel or microdermabrasion you'll need to give your skin 7 days before waxing.
Take care of your skin post wax//
This tip can be just as important as the set up for waxing. If you don't take care of your skin you can get irritation, redness, ingrown hairs and those pesky red bumps. Make sure to clean the area with mild soap when you get home. If your skin is irritated you can apply ice to reduce inflammation. If your skin is irritated you can apply a light layer of hydrocortisone cream. If your skin is calm a few hours after waxing, make sure to apply a good astringent followed by ice. Waxing can open your pores and to help reduce the chance of a break out later that will help.
