item.title: Alison Harper Style//Getting the best haircut before a big event
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
Whether you are coming up to the big day or have a hair cut or two between, follow these simple tips to help ensure you wont end up with a wedding day hair disaster! Often times we have clients who receive regular hair appointments but leading up to the wedding, they allow a bit more time between cuts. Whether you are allowing it to grow out, or just got busy; make sure to plan a haircut before the wedding day. It will make quite a difference in your hairstyle. Follow these tips and you'll be solid. xo
When// 2 weeks before event
2 weeks is the sweet, hair cut spot. Plan your cut and color accordingly. If you pay attention, usually a week after your fresh haircut, your cut starts to settle and looks its best. This is really important if you get bangs, after a week they lay better. On the flip side, you want to make sure that you don't go over 2 weeks if you get highlights or color. The only thing worse than having dead ends on your wedding day is having grown out color. So stick with two weeks and you'll be golden. Or brunette, or cool blond, or red..
Be Choosy// Don't skimp and Don't assume
First off, if you have a current stylist and you like like their work; stick to them. However if you weren't too excited about your last appointment you should do a little research and try someone new. Make sure that this person is well reviewed, has ample appointment time to see you and that you are comfortable with this person. Just because it is your wedding day doesn't mean you should have to go out to the most expensive salon in town to get the perfect look. On the flip side, you'll need to pay a moderate amount to get a decent amount of time with your stylist. Choose wisely!
Pay Attention// No streaky highlights
This tip is usually something no one thinks about. If you are getting highlights make sure to talk with your stylist about how you are wearing your hair for the wedding day. If your stylist is in a hurry, they may end up putting thick or uneven highlights around or near your face. When your hair is done, you'll want to pull it back as if in a pony tail and inspect your hairline. There will be a small amount of space from the scalp but around your hair line shouldn't look grown out or streaky. If for some reason you do end up with these results, do not hesitate to say something. Most stylists are willing to fix something if you aren't happy. If they push back, ask to speak with a manager. This isn't unreasonable and this is really important.
Bangs or not // Don't get wild
This is a little bit of common sense. If you have bangs, then get them trimmed as usual. If you are thinking about bangs and have never had them, you may want to wait. We don't suggest that you ever try anything severely different or trendy leading up to the wedding. Classic, remember?
Set up your Stylist for Success// Photos and timing
If you want to get the best service possible, you'll want to set your stylist up for success. When you set your appointment ask the receptionist when your stylist is least busy. If you make an appointment on a Saturday, expect to be a little hurried. Your stylist may have a full book of appointments and wont have the extra time to discuss highlight placement. If you plan a week day appointment, don't come right before the salon closes. This may not always be true, but your stylist may be tired. Imagine if you were asked to do something really important the last 15 minutes of your work day, its not going to get done with the same zeal as if you had been asked when you first came in. Make sure that you are early to your appointment, nothing is more frustrating to a stylist than having their entire day delayed because of one appointment. Remember, you'll want your stylist happy, refreshed and excited. Bring pictures too. Having a photo or two of your color or cut will help the stylist to get into your brain and understand exactly what you want. There are thousands of shades of blonde and occasionally you two could be on different pages entirely.
Helpful things to think about//
Always follow the advice of your wedding day updo stylist. In my experience, a hair cut with layering is always best. If you are planning on wearing your hair half up or half down, layering will help to get the cascading waves that you may be looking for. Colored hair will also hold curl a little better than natural. Just make sure you plan for a successful haircut and you wont be disappointed. If for some reason you are left unhappy, don't hesitate to say something. You are a paying client and it is your big day!

item.title: Personal//Rennfest & Family
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
Yesterday, my family and I went to the Maryland Renisance Festival. If you are from Maryland it is as traditional as eating crabs. You have to go, you have to stare and you have to eat a turkey leg. Well, this year our trip was even more eventful. First of all. My beautiful sister Caitlin and my soon to be brother in law got engaged!! I am beyond excited to welcome Matt into our family and to celebrate two people who were so clearly made for each other.

Eventually leading to the surprise. My aunt surprised them with a honeymoon trip to Italy! A far cry from the trip to the Olive Garden they thought they were getting based on card #4!
We are going to have a hard time topping this next year, wouldn't you say. xo

item.title: Alison Harper Style//At Home Masks For Happy & Healthier Hair
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
As you get close to your big event, there is a lot of prep involved. From eye brow waxes and tanning to getting your nails done. One thing I see overlooked is hair health. Most of the time brides-to-be have been growing their hair out for months, right before the wedding they get a very tiny trim so that they can keep all of the length in their hair. This combined with the fact that most soon to be brides are stressed and dieting; can lead to weak or lackluster locks. Don't worry girls, we've got two simple at home solutions for you! Try either recipe to fix you ailment and your hair will start to get healthier and happier by the treatment. Enjoy. xo
For Softer, Healthier Hair
Avocados are one of the only natural hair ingredients that can penetrate the hair cuticle, meaning that its softening abilities will stick around after you've rinsed this magic down the drain.
1/2 very ripe, mashed avocado 1/2 very ripe, mashed bananas 2 Tbsp of Olive Oil 1 eggPuree Banana and Avocado until no lumps are present. Mix in other ingredients. Apply to dry hair, cover with a shower cap or some other plastic wrap. Leave on for 30 minutes then wash hair. Follow with a nice conditioning shampoo and conditioner for even stronger results.
Photo Credit: Marie Claire
For Shinier, Healthier Hair
Apple Cider vinegar is another amazing kitchen ingredient. Its acidic properties will help clean off buildup on the hair shaft, while the oil will help add long lasting shine. Keep in mind if you have recently colored your hair to do this mask only once or twice as excessive use can dull color.
1 ripe banana 2 tsp. virgin coconut oil [or tea tree oil, avocado oil or olive in a pinch] 1 cup apple cider vinegarPuree Banana until no lumps are present. Mix in other ingredients. Apply to dry hair, cover with a shower cap or some other plastic wrap. Leave on for 30 minutes. Before shampooing, give a quick rinse with a bit more apple cider vinegar, then wash hair. Follow with a nice conditioning shampoo and conditioner for even stronger results.

item.title: Alison Harper Style//Operation Homefront
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
On Thursday we had the privilege to pamper some very special mom's to be. We are a part of the DC chapter of NACE, the National Association of Catering and Events. NACE partnered with Operation Homefront, a charity organization that helps military families in need. This moving event was hosted to pamper 50 military mom's that needed a little extra support. The moms were able to enjoy breakfast a little free baby shopping, hair and makeup by our team and free bump photos! After the pampering session, they had a delicious lunch, a few give aways and a pretty sweet surprise. Each mom received a bundle of baby items as well as a free Nuna stroller. It was such a sweet moment, we honored families who have given so much to each of us. I couldn't think of a more moving way to give back.
After the event, the planning team received a lovely note from one of the moms:
"I keep tearing up thinking how grateful I was to be a part of this event today. I hope everyone knows how much things like this are appreciated and I hope to one day be able to give back to Operation Homefront as much as ya'll have done for my family. It is nice to know that people still love the military and love helping the Service Member and their families. I can never express how much this organization means to me and how much you personally have changed many situations in my life."
I am truly honored that we were able to help support this cause and these women. I know that hair and makeup can be taken and washed off, but I am so glad that over all we were able to provide a few niceties to these women who deserve so much more. I want to make sure I highlight the amazing sponsors who gave to this event. I don't have a list but hopefully this picture will do the trick. xo
If you are looking to give, Operation homefront is an amazing charity that can always use giving individuals and sponsors. They have call to action needs that indviduals or bigger groups can help. Please visit them athttp://www.operationhomefront.net/dcmetro/ to see how you can help today.

item.title: Personal//This is the year
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
This is the year of high thread count sheets and better work-life balance. Of extra long dinners over wine, planning week long trips to anywhere but here. This is the year of finally understanding my worth, high heeled wedges and more expensive facial moisturizer. The time for less investment in what others think. The year of cooking nights with my husband, counting my blessings and perfume instead of body spray. The year I work on accepting that I am exactly where I am supposed to be. Of guiltless pumpkin spice lattes and regular pedicures. The year I'm going to finally invest in those really amazing faux-leather cropped pants I want so, so bad. This is the year of coffee and sun rises, of those few extra minutes of cuddling and trusting myself to fall for my husband over and over again. This is the year, and this is my year. Happy Birthday to me. 
Caitlin and I in our faux-iphone-80's-glamour shot by Anna Bruce Photography.

item.title: Personal//Happy Day
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
Today, our very beautiful office manager gets married. I have been lucky enough to consider Katy my dear friend. She was the first artist we added to our team and she has grown with my company and has worked along side me on this amazing dream I have. I could not be more thankful to have her on my side. Today I get to attend the wedding of Katy and her fiancee Ronnie. Words cannot describe how excited I am for the two of them.
Dear Katy, I cannot tell you how happy I am that you have found someone like Ronnie. The two of you are a perfectly molded match. You two have taught me things about my own marriage and are a beautiful example of respect, support and love. I am so happy to get to watch you walk down the aisle today. This day has been a long time coming. I am thinking of the two of you today and hoping for you both a lifetime of happiness, compromise and laughter. As always, I am full of advice you didn't ask for. I just wanted to say a few thoughts that were given to me on my wedding day. Marriage, as I am learning is like a small plant. If you leave it unattended and un-cared for it will wither and die. Eventually you will remove the decomposed plants' roots from your garden only to look for a new plant to fill the void. If you care for it, give it attention. Trim it, water it and talk to it -it will become the most beautiful, and full plant in your garden. It will bloom with beautiful flowers, produce vegetables. It will provide you with everything that you need, shade and food. As the old adage goes, the grass is green where you water it. I know that you and Ronnie will succeed. You have so many people rooting for the two of you. It is so exciting to see such raw, tangable love like I see between you two. I am sorry that this is so long, as I venture into overly creepy. I just wanted you to know that my heart is full for you today and I am excited for you and where this life will lead you. xo

item.title: Alison Harper Style//Short Hair Styling
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
Having short hair can sometimes prove to be a challenge when trying to compile your wedding day look. This post, is for my shorties. A little short, sweet updo inspiration. xo
Julianne Hough at the golden globes, twisted and pinned her hair back to give the illusion of longer hair. With a little volume on top and soft twisted sides. Perfect for someone who has a short, chin length bob haircut.
Photo Credit: People.com
This hairstyle, referred to as a Gibson Tuck is another short hair illusion trick. By tucking the ends up into a twist it gives the idea that there is more hair. For this style the front pieces of your hair by your ear should be able to reach back in to a very small pony tail.
Photo Credit: The Knot
Simple, yet effective is a classic standby. Soft curls and a side pulled up. This is perfect for someone who embraces their short hair and wants to show of those fabulous earrings!
Photo Credit: Pinterest
This sideways, french braid style is a good choice for someone with a lot of layering in their haircut. It can be full, secure and it also gets your hair up off of your face. For this style, your hair should be in a slightly longer bob hair cut.
Photo Credit: WeddingGoal.com
Faith Hill rocks the short hair and adores volume. This simple, classic standby is a great style for someone who likes a simpler style and embraces their hair length. With a sleeker style like this you can pull of a more dramatic makeup application or more dramatic jewelry.
Photo Credit: Pinterest
Keep in mind, if you have a pixie cut you can generally carry a much more dramatic hair accessory. Seen below, is a short, cropped cut with a stunning accessory. This is perfect for someone who loves their cut and wants to proudly show it off. You go, shorty.
Photo Credit: Pinterest

item.title: Personal//Easy Goes
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded: I went online a few days ago and I saw a pretty well known planners photo with her husband. The quote below "Marriage is easy" My first reaction, I thought 'oh that's sweet.' Before I got really bothered by the statement. The more I thought about it, the more bothered I was. Marriage isn't easy. For anyone. Ever. Yes, it has its beautiful, slow parts where things fall in place well, but it also has its struggles. Two humans are learning to cohabitate, they are from different backgrounds, different upbringings and have different thought patterns. Naturally, there are going to be adjustment periods, compromise and frustration. I just wanted to put one thing out into the cyber world to combat that theory, that if you are in a rough spot, adjusting and fighting for your marriage that you are doing something wrong. You are not, marriage isn't easy. It is a constant battle in which love wins. Jd and I are doing well, he supports me I care for him. He is my partner in life, I will always have his back and he will always be there holding my hand. Guess what, we've fought through some things. Its a constant growing thing, marriage. I just wanted to put that out there. If your marriage isn't easy right now, that's okay. Fight for this beautiful thing. xo

item.title: Personal//Support
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
Today, my team and I are getting geared up for a fabulous shoot at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in DC. Before I run out of the door and into the city I just wanted to take a quick moment to reflect. The other morning, I was rushing, huffingly late. Before I could slam the door behind me, Jd had made me an egg sandwich. The gesture stunned me. With how overwhelmed I've been with things of late, the fact that he got out of bed before the sun came up, snuck and made the eggs while I showered and then surprised me with a breakfast I was about to skip.. it was just too much. If I hadn't been running so late, I would have probably cried. I posted of facebook that afternoon asking what your person does to support you. The responses were so simple, yet so sweet. I just had to share them. It was such a beautiful testament to the fact that love can come in the simplest of forms. Love is an everyday, rudimentary task. Love is a hug from the back while cooking dinner, a car wash or an egg sandwich. I couldn't help myself and I'm sorry if I'm embarrassing anyone. I hope though, that this brightens your day a little, like it did mine.
xo

item.title: Personal//Guerrilla Handbook
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
A few years ago, a close friend was getting married. During her bridesmaids brunch, she handed out books to each of her ladies. "I picked ones that I thought suited each of you, and since most of you hadn't been in a wedding before, I thought they were perfect!" I watched her dashing older sister open a leather bound, classic white book; I watched another girl open a beautiful hard cover, grey book with a gold bookmark. I tore my wrapping paper off to find this. This pale yellow, paperback monstrosity. The overview reads: : In weddings as in war, it always helps to be well prepared." I flipped quickly through to see a chapter titled:
"The Tour of Duty Begins: Getting the bride what the bride wants"
Instantly offended, I shut the book. I gave a brief smile and threw it in the trash when I got home. I was put off, is this the kind of "friend" she thinks I am? I'm the friend who would get down and dirty for the bride, making sure she had the perfect day. I'm the one that would help wrangle her drunk uncle from making a scene, I'm the one who would send the florist back to the shop to "Get the RED roses she requested!" I wanted to be the friend who plans the classy bridal shower. The friend who helps organize the seating arrangements, the one she consults about etiquette. Not the low rung bridesmaid who would yell at the caterer. I was too embarrassed.
Years later, I still think of that book. My embarrassment and how people view me. This past weekend, I was with my little sister, dress shopping for her own wedding. We arrived bright and early on a Saturday morning, we'd made an appointment. She'd chosen dresses, we were ready. She didn't have a large party, just my little brother and I. We were going to make this exciting! Then they stuck us in the corner. Literally. I watched my little sisters face as they took the larger bridal parties into the big dressing rooms. You know, the ones with the little stage, special lighting. The ones with the seats for the bridesmaids and moms to sit in awe. I watched her face as we were put down the hallway into a cloistered dressing room. No seats for us to sit in, no mini stage. At first, I let that slide, maybe they were overbooked? Maybe they did this so we would have some privacy. As I glanced around, I listen to the clothier ignore my sisters requests. She had looked across the room and seen another bride in a beautiful, chiffon dress and requested to try a dress on with that style. Behind that bride, an empty, stage fronted, bridal dressing room.
When the woman returned to the room, without the dress; my blood started to boil. We were here, just like those other parties. My sister deserved to have a beautiful experience, bells and whistles. When she closed the dressing room door, I saw that look. The look my little sister gives me when she's feeling defeated. A "why did we even bother look" Something in me snapped. I snatched the little sign off the door, my little brother yanked the dresses and we moved ourselves to that empty dressing room with a stage. While my sister was changing in her original room, I went up front and told the staff our clothier was rude and we wanted someone else. My brother and I went into the back of the store and grabbed the dress she wanted to try on. She was going to have this experience and it was going to be beautiful.
I realized this weekend that my friend had been right. I am that bridesmaid that would send the florist packing, that would fight for the clean hotel room, the one that would make sure that everyone bought the same shoes. I would fight for the bride to have a beautiful experience. As offended as I once was, I am not ashamed of that book anymore. I am that girl for the people I care about. Everyone should have someone who fights for them this way. For my sisters sake, I'm glad I can stand up for her and fight for her bells and whistles. xo

item.title: Personal//Monday Inspiration
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
We all have those days, we roll over and get up. While we get up, we don't actually wake up. I've been having a series of these days, we all have them. The fog of sleep never left my brain, I'm running on neutral and no amount of coffee can undo the lack of umpf I have. These days are okay, no one can be fully on 100% of the time. The key with having a day or two like this is to focus on climbing out. Whenever I feel this way, thankful less and less often as I get older; I decide to get inspired. The best way for me to climb out a funk is to get my brain pumping. When you are feeling this way, inspiration is everywhere yet you can miss it. So on this lovely Monday morning, I want to inspire you. If you are feeling lackluster, here is a list of things that inspire me and places I gain inspiration from.
Music//
There is something about getting my groove on that helps clear the fog for me. I love music and the poetry behind the lyrics stays with me all day.
"Feeling my way through the darkness Guided by a beating heart I can't tell where the journey will end But I know where to start They tell me I'm too young to understand They say I'm caught up in a dream Well life will pass me by if I don't open up my eyes So wake me up when it's all over When I'm wiser and I'm older All this time I was finding myself And I didn't know I was lost" -Avicii
Instagram// oliphantstudio
This studio has an active instagram chock full of stunning images. Annie Leibovitz and others, I could stare at them for hours. I follow maybe 15 artists on instagram.
Vouge//
Always a source of inspiration for me is Vouge. I could just sift through the ads and feel like I've touched something beautiful. It works for me everytime.
In case you cant find your sources here are a few things that spoke to me today. Happy Monday, go take over the world. xo

item.title: Real Wedding//Stephanie & Kyle
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
Stephanie and Kyle were married in a extraordinary way here in DC. They had their hearts set on their friend Scott marrying them. He became ordained, plans were made and then due to some difficult Virginia laws; he wasn't allowed to marry them at their venue. So what did they do? They had a super intimate mini ceremony during their first look, just the two of them. This way they could have the best of both worlds, a sweet private ceremony officiated by their good friend and then a larger, slightly more legal one for family and friends. Each tiny detail was thought through. It was a beautiful wedding. I just can't wait for you to see Stephanie's reactions. She had some of the best faces! Congrats to you both for not only taking this massive leap into marriage but for doing it your own way. The best way for the both of you. xo
Many thanks to Carly Rehberg Photography for sharing these beautiful images!

item.title: Personal//Thankful
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
This thanksgiving my thoughts and prayers are with a very dear friend of mine. One of my best friends lost her daughter this week. This, this..tragedy has happened to such an amazing set of parents. It pulls on my heart. Gabby was born prematurely and fought her entire life. This young angel graced us for only a short time and her little life has touched so many people. This thanksgiving I am thankful for this little fighter and for the moments we had with her.  I am thankful that she has given me the ability to reflect on my life and to put things into perspective. This thanksgiving I am thankful for the beauty that surrounds me, for my family and friends I consider family. I am thankful for this life, for each day. Above all, I am thankful for sweet blessings like Gabby. Happy Thanksgiving xo
If you feel it in your heart, there is a support page for my friend and her family. http://www.gofundme.com/5hl43g

item.title: Personal//Compromise
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
Just two nights ago, my husband and I had a full blown, political style vote in our living room. He wanted football, I wanted Christmas music and ornaments. He wanted to order pizza and I wanted warm, southern style food. We were on two very different tracks for our evening when I turned to him.
"Okay, while I make meatloaf and mash potatoes, you can watch the game." He responded "While you make meatloaf, I'll set a fire in the fireplace." I nodded, "Okay, when I'm done in the kitchen you can watch your game with the volume turned down and we can play Christmas music in the background."
We proceeded to negotiate how many times he was aloud to yell at the TV over Bing Crosby. It was a heated debate of giving and taking a little. I know that this doesn't sound like much, or it sounds insane to you. Either way, this was a pivotal move for us. Compromise is when two sides meet a mutual agreement. In most cases, until the great Christmas tree debate of 2013; one of us has just given to the other. Its selfless and beautiful but restricting and frustrating to have a marriage like that. There can be guilt in getting your way and there can be resentment in stepping aside. Like this very juvenile negotiation, we are learning to exercise our give and take, flexing those muscles at the same time. It was beautiful. In the end I shamelessly sung my off key version of Mariah Carey's Christmas album while he occasionally gazed off at the silent tv with an ornament in his hand. Better than last year and perfect for us.

item.title: Personal//F. Scott Fitzgerald
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded: A friend shared this quote a few days ago and I have been thinking about it since. It is such a perfect quote, so fitting for life and who you are or will become. As a woman, I am a constant and ever changing person, as a business owner I go with the tides and see where life will lead me. As a wife, I hold on tight, love with all that I have. As a friend I experience their excitement and sorrows and as a listener I become a storyteller. I hope to live a life I am proud of too. xo

item.title: Ask The Artist/Which mascara should I buy?
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
12/11/2013 5 Comments
I get asked a lot of questions. It seems as though every woman has questions about hair and makeup. Since I've been getting so many, I figured -why not go to the true professionals. Ask my artists. So, please enjoy this new segment! xo
------
Dear Alison, I am not a huge makeup wearer but I always have on mascara. The only problem is that there are so many different kinds, I either end up with a mascara that's too clumpy or the brush is terrible. I finally reached my breaking point, after using cheap mascara for a while, I splurged and I purchased a really expensive mascara. It ended up being just as bad. Do you have any suggestions on which mascara to get? Sincerely, Lackluster Lashes
Jen Lee
My go to mascara is "Lights, Camera, Lashes" by Tarte because it's one of the only waterproof and natural based mascaras that isn't bad but it also does not irritate my eyes. If you are looking for a drug store alternative I would suggest "Mega Plush Volume" by Maybeline because it also does not irritate eyes and it also does not flake off.
Abby
I prefer NARS larger than life mascara. It contains vitamin E and oils that help strengthen lashes and it offers a beautiful finished and glossy look.
Sierra
My favorite to use is Chanel "Le Volume de Chanel" in both black and violet colors. It has an amazing brush that grabs the lash at the base and really gives a plush, full effect to the lashes.
Libby
 I love Max Factor's masterpiece max- but seeing as you can't get it in the US any more, I also love Lancôme's hypnose doll lashes. It separates, isn't clumpy, smells like rose water (like diorshow), and has a tapered brush to help you get into the corners easily!
Tiffany
I second the Lancôme hypnose but in waterproof because it doesn't clump up, builds up volume and holds a curl. For a drugstore alternative I would suggest cover girl lash blast, also waterproof. Mainly because any lashes that are stick straight, the waxy waterproof formula helps hold the curl.

item.title: Ask The Artist//Dealing with fine and thin hair
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
12/18/2013 4 Comments
Dear Alison, I saw this feature last week and I had to email you. I've always struggled with having thin hair. I've tried short hair cuts and different products but my hair either falls flat after a few hours or the products are too heavy and my hair looks just sad. Do you r your artists have any suggestions for what I could do? Sincerely, Furiously flat
Photo Credit: My Fashion Cents
Kaitlyn
I second dry shampoo, my favorite is bed head "Dirty Secret" another great product is bed head's "sugar dust." You apply it at your roots and it adds a lot of volume and texture to your hair. Another suggestion is getting a highlights. Lightening some of your hair will add texture to fine hair. When I blow my hair out I pin each section once I'm done into a curl. Then spray it, let it set, then flip my head over and shake it out. Once it is loose I spray with a finishing spray. I have fine hair so using a strong hold never works well with me, unless its up.
Caitlin
Dry shampoo! It's something I recommend for all of my clients. Especially those who have fine or thin hair for two reasons. One, dry shampoo will control oil long into the work day. Two, it also allows you to get a second day out of your style. I recommend it for day to day hair but I also use it when I'm working on an updo.

item.title: This is a Test Post
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded: This is test content.

item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
I woke up the morning of the wedding with the sun. I was so so excited. Somehow, the serious amount of wine I had drank the night before didn't effect me at all. I wanted to throw open the windows on this beautiful February morning and yell. Today, I will marry him. The man I was made to marry. My dress was in its bag, my glitter heels, veil and necklace were ready to go. I could have put the dress on at 6 am. But, it was a little too early for that. I knew it was too early, I was in a room with some of my family and I'd just have to force myself back to sleep.


I rolled over and my mom was wide awake too. I nudged her, "let's get coffee" We snuck out of our hotel room leaving my little brother and his friend on the pull out couch snoring. I didn't even glance in the mirror. We stepped on the elevator while the whole hotel was sleeping. I remember looking over at her and chuckling, her hair was a mess, she had on my little brothers flip flops and we hadn't even changed out of our pjs. I probably looked worse. We strolled by the front desk and I'm sure they chuckled too. 



My mom and I spent the next hour sipping coffee and talking. I can't honestly remember what we talked about. All I remember is that we talked about everything and anything. It was an amazing start to my wedding day. Pjs, coffee, bed head -just my mom and I. Growing up as one of five children you kind of get stuck in the shuffle. As a middle child you get grouped in a lot of the time. I've spent time alone with my mom before but never like this. We had fought, argued and cried with this wedding planning. Anything that I chose she wanted the opposite. Anything she suggested I hated. We didn't see eye to eye with this wedding at all. It was the most amazing, magical 6 months but also the most tedious and frustrating. Sitting in that little dinner across the table from my mom in all her bed-headed glory, I could tell she was happy and excited for me. All of that frustration and arguing was behind us. I've never felt as connect to my mom as I did during our coffee sun rise talk. Her calm confidence that this was the perfect step for me made me calm and confident. I knew that this was right. I just knew it.

Home Made Sugar Scrub

06/18/2012

0 Comments

 

The other night I was lounging on the couch watching shark tank on my dvr when Jd sat down. 
Using my sweet peripheral vision, I slowly guided my feet to his lap and started nudging him. 


When he looked down I wiggled my toes in an enticing "Rub me" kind of way.
The look of pure horror on his face was indescribable. 



Yes, pure horror. 
Okay, I might be getting a little dramatic but I really really wanted a foot rub. 
He bit his bottom lip and shook his head. 


To answer your question, yes I get pedicures. 
Often, in fact my nail lady knows I always get
Coney Island Cotton Candy when I walk in the door. 
Sometimes though, even after a fresh pedi my feet get kinda dry and ick looking. 
One thing that never goes out of style is soft, smooth skin. 
I started making a little at home scrub and it  works fabulously every where. 



I thought I would share! 
There are tons of variations every where but this one is pretty simple. 
 
Photo Cred: Deliciously Organized Blog


Ingredients: 
-1/2 cup sugar
or Sea Salt 
(depending on the amount of exfoliation you'll need)

- Enough cold-pressed oil to dampen the mixture
(olive, wheat germ, peanut, corn, or sunflower) 





Gently massage this exfoliating scrub all over your body and face before you shower with a light soaping and rinse. 
Repeat whenever you want a foot rub from your husband.

I'll follow up sometimes with a little aloe vera gel on my tootsies when I'm ready for flip flops.

xo, 
Alison

Fashion Friday: Love & Lust

06/18/2012

0 Comments

 
We've been a little lacking in the blog department. We're sorry. Really we are. All those "changes" I mentioned in the last blog post have been sucking up all my extra time. haha, extra time. I love that. I haven't seen "extra time" since 2009. I am sure you can relate. To make up for it I had a really stellar idea. Fashion Friday. When I wake up on Fridays I always want to step my game up. I wake up Fridays wanting to wear heels and actually contemplating doing my hair. In case you were curious, I work from my home office, with only my dog. Blowing out my hair is like a huge break from normal. I don't know why but Fridays remind me of those school days when Friday was pizza day, free play in gym and the day your teacher let everyone play 7up. Yeah, I just went there. Don't get too nostalgic on me, I've got a whole post to write here. 

I often stumble upon amazing photos of things I love, ahem -pintrest- and never know where to find them or even how to start. Most of the time I discover that these images are from styled shoots or magazines with clothing, jewelry and accessories from some pretty top notch designers. Top notch designers equals top notch pricing. I don't know about you, but this girl likes a deal. Especially when I change things out of my wardrobe so quickly, I can't justify spending crazy amounts on certain things. When I see something on clearance, or discounted, in my head I squeal and wave my tight little fists. In reality, I casually look around to make sure no one gets it before me and jam it in my basket like a squirrel hoarding nuts. Cool, calm and affordable. Which leads me to this weeks edition of Fashion Friday: Love & Lust. 


 
I have a major hard core case of want with this photo. Its like a fabulous version of dress up. 
Lets take a look. 




Lust:
 
Love:  
 


So, love this? I have to admit- $38 for a ring is still a bit for me, but I can see myself wearing thatallthetime. Do you not love this look? 
I hope you have the most fabulous Friday! 

Stay Fierce! 
Xo, 
Alison

item.title: Personal//A little perspective
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
I remember it like a it was yesterday. Not actually like yesterday, because I occasionally forget what I wore yesterday. I remember it like it was a really intense dream. I was wearing sweats in case you were curious. I was a high school freshman. A high school freshman with mono. A high school freshman with mono in sweats. 

For days, -eternity- I couldn't move from the couch. The tv was too far away, the couch was too small and it was way too hot in my mothers cluttered living room. First I was cold, then I was colder. Then I was hot. With the little voice I had, I complained. I whined like a typical teenager. I was tired and achy and I felt clammy and I couldn't decide if I was hungry. I whined and complained when my mom wouldn't pay me enough attention, like she could magically rid me of the symptoms. I wheezed and I couldn't believe my luck. 

Here I am, exhausted. Barely able to move from my moderately temperate couch, barely able to keep down a very vegetarian homemade broth my mom made. Barely able to bear this temporary disease. I couldn't believe I was missing class, my friends. Missing cheerleading practice -man, at this rate I will probably miss the football game this weekend too. Life is not fair. How, how did I get this kind of luck. 

Man, why wont my mom turn down the news? Its so loud in hear. I reach and strech my tired arm while I turn my head and..and.. before I realized it I was watching a live news feed. Time stopped. 

 

Wait, why is that plane so close to that building? Hold on, is that on fire? I choke out. I can barely speak, so I slap the coffee table. Slamming the remote down. Skin on wood, panic. My mom comes in and drops the phone. It is pure silence in my living room as we watch that second plane cascade into the second building.  Complete confusion.


I can barely explain the emotion, and panic that crossed my moms face as she started to comprehend what was going on. I was 14, I didn't even know what the world trade center was. In the worlds slowest second she turned her head and said, "oh, ohh. That's New York. There are people.. people in there"


Noting moved. For so long. Slowly, it made sense to me. That was an accident or on purpose. I just witnessed in real time one of our countries largest tragedies. While my mind quickly raced through thoughts "how can people get out of there", "-wait, how many people are in there" Hold on.. "is that someone jumping?"

 
Robert Peraza kneels by his son's name at the National September 11 Memorial & Museum on Sept. 11 


That day I received the largest dose of perspective. I will never forget that morning. That morning god handed me a massive attitude adjustment. I will never understand the choas of being in those buildings. I will never understand what it is like to go to work on a normal day and never come home. I will never understand grieving someone with an empty casket. That day I will never forget.

item.title: Personal//Similarly Different
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
This Tuesday morning, we're going to get real personal. Like, meet my shoe collection personal. As I'm growing in my marriage, I'm learning that life is long. That things are not perfect. People are not perfect. No one told me when I picked out that white dress how challenging being married could be.

Let me clarify that I would not change a second of it. I love my husband, even with all of his idiosyncrasies. Like using two dryer sheets instead of one. [One can do the job. Two is a waste. Seriously.] As we grow I am realizing that it isn't how alike we are, or how much we parade our likeness. We're different. Very different. Sometimes that is the biggest challenge  Understanding him and he getting me.  I was laying in bed one morning when I realized the symbolism of our pair of closets. 

Meet our closets; a view from my very comfortable memory foam. 
I warned you it would get personal.
 
His & Hers

From the outside, they look alike. An adorable matching pair. Clean simple doors, matching handles. Even. Similar. On the inside however, well, not so much.

My husband is quiet, driven, clean. Hard working.  Simple. Not simple like stupid. He's definitely not stupid. Simple like basic. Simple like put him on an island with a pack of matches and he'll get all 'Bear Grylls' on you. Simple. Strong.

I'm a bit more of an extrovert. I don't like when people don't like me. I can get loud, talkative. I don't think I owned a pair of tennis shoes until our hiking trip around Arizona. I'm melodramatic and complicated -in a sweet way. I think.

 
His & Hers

We're different. When he buys a new shirt, he throws one away. He owns 3 colored shirts. In the bottom of his closet he has 3 pairs of shoes. 3 baskets for dry cleaning, dress socks and white gym socks. 

My closet is an explosion of color. [I actually cleaned up the floor of it for you] There is organization in there. somewhere. That is a basket of high heels. I keep my winter, summer in there. I've got scarves, purses, riding helmets and nail polish. In fact, those board games and bag full of purses you see in my husbands closet? I put those there. 

This is a very clear symbol of the difference in our personalities, living style, approach to all of it. We're different. At our core, we different. Somehow we click though. My stuff magically spills into his closet at times. On the rare occasion that I do laundry, I put his clothing back just how he likes it. I respect the basket rule and he doesn't complain that I have three pair high heels that look practically the same. 

Even though we are so different we are learning to accept each others quirks. We respect each other, we make it work. There is a balance to it. I swear. I'm not sure why I am sharing this. Maybe in hopes to show that there is challenge to marriage. There is work, differences and acceptance. It isn't candy corn and rainbows. It can be happy and rewarding  and you don't have to be alike. You can be different.

item.title: Alison Harper Style//Time
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
I don't have spare time. At all. I have a gym membership I haven't used in 3 months. I made my husband microwave his own frozen burrito last night because I didn't have time to make dinner. [To his horror.] I just don't have a spare minute to myself. I'm a hungry small business owner. I have to force myself to relax at times and carve out an evening with my ladies. I just don't have extra. Really any where. 

When Karen Buck of wedding 411 emailed me and asked if My ladies and I would be willing to donate our time and talent for this cause I knew I couldn't say no. You know that saying "Everyone, knows someone affected by breast cancer"Well. Its true. I haven't suffered from this life stealing disease but it has touched my life in a distant way. 


My mother has nine siblings. One of my aunts married my solid, gregarious Cuban uncle. He had a sister. When I was young she and my mom were close friends. She rented the basement apartment of my parents house. Her children were raised side by side with my siblings and I. In fact you could hear her yelling "I used to change your diapers!!!" at me at Christmas parties. 

She was a loud, vivacious, funny and a loyal woman. She was diagnosed with breast cancer right around her second daughters birth over 17 or so years ago. She fought, she had surgeries, she had treatments. She won. She raised two successful and beautiful daughters. Until this year. The cancer came back. It came back with a vengeance. She fought. She fought hard but she didn't win. 

Although it has been a few years since her daughters and I had sleep overs, birthday parties and truth or dare challenges. This loss has touched me. She was a really great mom. She lost her life to a cancer that we should have a cure for. She left behind two brilliant daughters and a whole family of people who love her. 

I know this is far fetched and may be crazy talk, but when I was asked if I would cut out time for this event I couldn't say no. I needed to do this for me. I needed to do this, because in some far off way... the proceeds from this event could help a family from losing their mother, sister, cousin or friend. I could definitely cut out time for this. 


Last night a few of our Alison Harper ladies and I traveled out to the Maryvale Castle for the Brides Against Breast Cancer Cinderella event. It was an awesome fashion show and really fun. We worked along side other hair and makeup teams, updos for i dos, fresh faces by Cindy. A ton of local vendors, charm city cakes, gala cloths all donated their time. Even if we raised one dollar it was worth it. 

The event is also happening tonight. There is still time if you'd like to attend. We'd love to see you, when we do it all again. Click here for more information. 



 
Decor and accessories! That is a cake!



 
Journey and Jen hard at work



 
Models & Dresses.



 
Jen, Journey and I after a long hard evening of beautiful people.

item.title: Personal//This Is The Year
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
This is the year of exposed legs. Not being ashamed to roll up to a networking event singing Carrie Underwood's "blown away" in my old Ford Taurus. Its the year of getting to know my clients, accepting that my hair is short and that I'll never be 5'8. The year of game nights, date nights and relaxing bubble bath nights. The year I start matching my underthings, like a real adult. The year I work hard, but relax harder. This is the year I realize and accept that I am not built for skinny jeans, halter tops or knee high boots. The year I learn to mind my own and be happy with what I have. The year I pray and blog more often. The year of regular pedicures, good books and scarves. I don't wear enough scarves. This is the year. This is my year. 


Happy Birthday to me. ..xo

item.title: Real Wedding//Mariel & Ryan
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
I get a lot of photos from our clients. I get them from planners and photographers too. There are only a handful that make you stop and marvel. Mariel and Ryan were married this September at the Engineers Club in Baltimore. As I glided through the photos that Marcella Treybig Photography sent over. I was in awe. I know that one of the hardest parts of wedding planning is making everything look cohesive. Mariel did that beautifully. She reached out to us a little while back to see if we had some lovely ladies to make everyone look fabulous for her September wedding. She gathered up her 6 closest ladies and invited us in. Enjoy! 
Xo, 
Alison


Hair and Makeup: 
Gabriela
Tami 
Abigail

item.title: Personal//Do It Yourself
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
So I've recently been getting this slew of really sweet emails from my past clients. You see, when a beautiful bride books with us we have a phone appointment. This can last any where from twenty minutes to an hour and a half. Really depends on how chatty we're feeling and how much coffee I've consumed. This process helps me to ensure I'm pairing our new lady with the best artist for her party. This is also a really awesome way for me to connect to our clients and to get to know them. 


In the past few weeks I've been getting a few emails from our newly married mentioning how inspired they were by my story and how it pushed them to get out there on your own. I'm not really sure why I'm sharing this. I'm just so stinking excited for them. 


You see, working for yourself and stepping out on the ledge of"Istillhavetopaymyrent/thisbetterwork" is really really scary. It takes guts, stamina, organization and tons of self motivation. Even with all the blood sweat and tears, the frustrations and stress. At the end of the day it is completely worth it. Every day I get up and I do what I love. I work with people I like, I am passionate. It doesn't even feel like work when you enjoy it. 


If you aren't passionate about what you are doing, you are doing the wrong thing. I wouldn't change a day in my life, I'm so happy that I jumped off that cliff. It worked. I gave it a try and even if it didn't work, at least then I would have know that I gave it a try. 

If you are thinking about getting out there on your own, do it. Take the first step, do a little research. I had NO CLUE how to build a business. [I sometimes still don't! -don't tell anyone] Every day you just wake up and walk forward. If you want it, you work for it and it'll happen. 


Get out there. 
Xo, 
Alison


Ps. Congrats: Evan [Sweets by E]  Kristin [Eleven Pepper Studios] and Andrea [Event Planner] I am super proud of each of you ladies!! 


 
At a networking event, fellow business women & entreprenuers 
Sarah Kahn, Yours truly, Lisa O'Quinn & Joy Nichols

item.title: Personal//National Boss' Day
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
It was a foggy Tuesday morning as I walked through the doors of La Madeline with my folder in hand. I stepped inside the door, readjusted my skirt and patted my hair. Too nervous to eat anything I ordered a cappuccino. That's what mature women drink, right? I find a comfortable two top near the faux fire place and set up camp. 

At this point I am beyond excited, I'm nervous -I want this to go well. Minutes later a very beautiful woman a few years older than I walks over, "Alison?" Startled, like I didn't expect her my eyes go wide "Gabriela?" after a few hugs and simple greetings we sit down with our coffee. 


 

Before this conversation I prepped myself 'don't talk too much', ' don't sound too green', 'make sure you put only the better things out there', 'she's older, She's worldly, so make sure she doesn't think you are too immature' 

You see, I was hiring my first artist. Up until this nerve racking coffee date it had been my sister, Katy one of her friends and I. We needed help. I knew we were headed for better things and I knew I should start bringing good solid people on board. The only catch? I had never been a boss before. 


Like ever. I was always the lowly starbucks barista, the stylist in the 4th chair down and the register girl at the IKEA. What did I know about overseeing things, telling people what to do and handling problems? Nothing. That's right, no training. So I did what I have always done with this company. Smiled. Smile and walk right through it. Deal with it as they come.


I explained to Gabriela that we were a budding company. We talked about the philosophy of this business. We talked about how I wanted to provide clients with an amazing experience and how I wanted to create an uplifting supportive work environment. I handed her a simple black folder with our menu in it and smoothed the lapels of my blazer jacket during our very professional lunch and prayed she couldn't guess how young I was. I needed her. She was talented, professional, gutsy and had a really amazing attitude. I was nervous she would turn down what I was offering, that she wouldn't see my vision and she'd take her leather bound professional portfolio with her. 


Much to my surprise she loved it. She loved everything. She joined our team and has been here since the beginning. Just a few weeks ago we had a good laugh about our first meeting about 2 years ago and she explained that she never doubted what I was doing for a second. She said she saw my vision, she saw what I stood for and wanted to be a part of it all. When I asked her if she could tell I was nervous and scared she would say no, she reassured me that I looked as professional as ever. 


Thank you to my amazing team of artists. I am so thankful to have a team behind me that furthers my vision, stands for the same morals, supports each other and makes me feel like I've got it all together. Even when I don't. 

In the words of the great Micheal Scott:

"Would I rather be feared or loved? Easy, both. I want people to be afraid of how much they love me. "


 
Xo, 
Alison

item.title: Alison Harper Style//Rules OF Engagement
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
Listen up.

1. Ask permission
      Ask my dad, no dad; ask mom. Ask someone, listen to their advice. This 
     shows me that you have considered my family and their thoughts. If you 
     are a good partner, you have nothing to fear. This is important to bridge the 
     gap from my childhood family to the family we will create together. 

2. Make it a complete surprise 
      This moment will only happen once, I will retell it when I am 89. Its pretty 
     important. Make it a complete surprise. 

3. Get someone to catch it on camera 
      This moment will be pure emotion, -private. This is a pledge to your future 
      person. That person, your emergency contact, your cell phone plan sharer, 
      the second parent to your kids -your person. Never again will you lay your 
      heart on the line for me so privately. Capture it, that moment the words 
      dance off of your lips, while time stands still. Capture that moment that I 
      absorb everything and when I finally say yes. I want a photo of that kiss. 
      Not just the one at the altar, I want the raw emotional moment when we 
      agree to change our lives, just between us. Every time I look at those photos 
      I will remember this life altering moment. 
 
4. Get down on one knee 
     This shows me that you are willing to give me this. This moment. Show me 
     that you are willing to get on your knee. Show me that you will take care of 
     me, that you can be vulnerable willing to compromise and care about my 
     response. If you don't do this, it will pass through my mind years later. I'm 
     not sure why, its just one of those things. 

5. Let my best friends help with the ring
     This is the least important option on the list but if you want to do this 
     perfectly, ask for help. I will love whatever you choose. Really I will but my 
     best friends have seen my pinterest board, they know I wear white gold not 
     yellow gold and they can help get my ring size. You don't have to tell the 
     world but its nice to know my friends helped.


 
These amazing engagement photos of Jd and I were taken by the fabulous Christine Barker 

Xo, 
Alison

item.title: Alison Harper//Business
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
Let me first start this post off humbly. I by no means have it all together. Really, I lock myself out of the house on a regular basis. That is the epitome of not having it all together. With that being said, I've dealt with a lot of business growth over the last 2 and a half years. With the volume of clients, artists, learning experiences and challenges I've worked through; I might boldly state that I am an expert in challenges. [ha-ha!]

I should clarify that although I have been in business for a smidge over 2 years I have had a strong and fast learning curve. We have completed over 475 weddings to date; 256 this year alone and over 25 photo shoots this year. I currently have two branch managers and  25 artists on my rooster. I am not telling you this to brag, please please don't take it this way. I am telling you this to explain our growth and to help explain my qualifications. Please know that I don't believe any of this would be possible without the most amazing, talented and loyal artists. 

 
Our very first wedding. July of 2010. Natalie was an sweet client with a fabulous set of bridesmaids.

Recently I've been getting quite a few emails and voice mails from other artists. A few of them just wondering how I structure my business, how I deal with this situation or that situation.  The most common request I receive is "Do you have any advice or tips?" 

That's a really broad question and I never really know how to answer. First off, I am so unbelievably flattered that anyone would take their time out to even email me. When I hear these messages, I want to reach through the computer and hug them. It is so refreshing and sweet to receive such messages. I wish I could tell them exactly what they need to know. The problem is, I don't know what they need to know. So, I've decided to start a series of posts that pertain to my business and lessons I've learned. I hope that by sharing these experiences, something from one of these posts will help at least one business owner to grow or even to know that they are not alone in their challenges.

 
Caitlin hard at work on Emilie's hair. Thank you Michelle Lindsay Photography for the image!


Since I've written so much in this first post [and embarrassingly so] I've decided that today I will keep it simple. No matter what industry you are in, you will face challenges working for yourself. No one will understand your struggles or  the stress that is applied to you. No one will loose sleep, staying up all night working but you. The anxiety from the moment you overbook, overspend or rely on someone who didn't come through. No one will understand that moment you lay your head on your desk and just cry. 

At the exact same time, no one will revel in the joy of your success like you will. No one will get the same giddy feeling when a client leaves you a stunning review. You alone are responsible for this. You alone will will feel that amazing feeling when a client recommends you to someone else, the moment you nail that hairstyle, photo or makeup application you were aiming for, the moment you have that extra $30 to buy your husband dinner. No one will get the same feeling you do on that day that bride looks at your work and cries those happy tears. Or that one Tuesday you want to sleep in and skype from your bed. You made that happen. You have built this business from nothing with your two hands. 

There are definite struggles in owning a business but understand that as long as the good out ways the bad it is completely worth every minute. When it feels the hardest just keep walking. That's it. Here's to you, owning your business. Taking the reins into your own hands and one day being able to retire on your yacht. [That is a joke. I don't even like boats.]


Make sure you check back in, I'll hopefully be blogging about this topic a bit. The next business post I have scheduled is,




                             The keys to building and maintain an amazing team.

xo, 
Alison

item.title: Real Wedding//Victoria & JD
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
A little while back, I spoke with Victoria about her wedding. I almost fell out of my chair when she told me her would be husband was called 'JD'. Which, creepily enough is what we call my husband. It took all I had to not yell out "HUSBANDnameTWINS!! Canwebebestfriends?!" 

We talked a little more about her husband and it turned out that they met when he was an exchange student from Spain in the 90's. She wanted to make sure that their wedding encompassed both their cultures since both families would be meeting at the wedding. The guests were traveling from all over the world. It turned out beautifully. They each said their vows in the others native language. They had an intimate ring warming ceremony, where the guests could bless their rings and the ceremony was bilingual. 

The neatest thing about their wedding was that they had their own private ceremony on New years eve and eloped. This wedding was their way of honoring their friends and families and bringing it all together. I remember Victoria telling me how happy she was that they did it this way, it took away all of the pressure and jitters so she could just enjoy the day. 

Thank you to Yasmina Cowan for sharing these beautiful photographs of their day. We were so excited that their wedding was featured on United with Love!
Enjoy, 
Alison

item.title: Alison Harper//Building a Team
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
As part of my new business blog series I promised to discuss building and maintaining a team. I know that this is a pretty hot button issue for most artists. Its a scary little jump, how do you trust someone else out on their own? How do you make sure they don't steal your business.. the list goes on. Here are some helpful tips when deciding to add to your army.


1. Make sure you are ready to have a team. 
    Sit back and really think about this one. Once you start to add, there really isn't any going back. Yes, it may add to your profit and help build your business name but it will almost immediately double your work load. Make sure that you are at a point where you really can release some of the work to someone else and that when they are trained properly that you are mentally ready to let them do it on their own. [I'm talking to you, type-a-ers] 

2. Get your paperwork set up.
    Once you've decided to get going contact your lawyer, accountant and insurance provider. Depending on your state [each are different] you will want to have some type of contract written up. Your lawyer can handle that and tell you in about 15 minutes the next steps needed, legally. Your insurance provider will need to update your coverage. My insurance didn't even change in price when I started a team and had under 3 other artists. 


 
Gabriela hard at work with our bride Moina

3. Start hiring.
    I am always hiring. I will hire even if I don't have work for someone [I will make sure to tell them that! -ha]. I never want to turn down talented, driven artists. I am always "hunting" [as my mom calls it] If my grocery bagger mentions that her little sister just finished hair school, like clockwork you'll hear "Is she looking for a job?" My best artists come from referrals or hunting. Ask around. I will trust a friend of a friend before I'll ever trust Craigslist [not to knock it, craigslist has some awesome finds and isn't a bad idea if you are new to the area]. 

     When you do come across someone you may think to hire, do an interview! I know that this sounds like a no brainier but I can't tell you how many small business owners don't! They feel like its a bit pretentious to bring someone into your home office to interview. Don't think this way. If you start off on the professional foot, your artists will carry that through. When you interview ask to see their work, skill set and resume. 

4. Let them know what they are in for. 
     The best policy when dealing with a staff/team/group is honesty. Be clear with them on payment expectations, work load and your expectations. You will get a lot farther with honesty. When I started with a team we had 3 weddings booked a month. I laid it out honestly, surprisingly the girls stuck around because they believed in what I was doing and knew that eventually it would be successful. 

     Also, people are not mind readers. You have to put every thing on paper. Everything. People have different versions of professionalism. You may think all black, with slacks, close toed shoes and hair and makeup done is "dressing professionally"; the new makeup artist you hired might think that her silver bra straps that match her flip flops is "dressing professionally."


 
Katy hard at work with our bride Amanda
Photo credit: Darling Photographers

I hope that this helps a few of you looking to branch out. Please leave me some feedback if there is something you'd prefer to hear about! 


Look for our next Business Post about Contracts!

item.title: Personal//Nate & Jacob
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
Disclaimer: I don't normally get political, I feel that everyone is entitled to your opinion. However, this is a fundamental liberty that should be offered to everyone. It hits very close to home to my family and I. I apologize -if this offends you, then you should stop reading. 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


    I wont ever forget hearing the story of Nate and Jacob. I was working in a small salon in College Park when the stylist next to me leaned over with a look in her eyes and said "I have no idea what to tell him." I sat and listened as she cut his hair, speechless. What do you say in this situation? What can you say?

Nate was an older gentleman, slight, friendly, calm with a little grey hair. I'd seen him come to Lynn for trims every two weeks like clock work. He always had a soft smile and otherwise, you didn't hear much from him. As I sat listening, I discovered his struggles. I was appalled.  It turns out that he and his partner had been together for 27 years. When his partner was diagnosed with Stage IV cancer, his death had come quickly and quietly. It had spread from his prostate, to stomach and a few other organs before they were able to even know what had hit him. 

As sad as that was there was another series of blows Nate would have to endure. While watching the love of his life pass into a coma he discovered the limitations he would suffer. You see, Nate and Jacob weren't able to marry. In Jacobs lifetime same-sex marriages were barely legal in Massachusetts.  Apparently, Jacobs very small and estranged family hadn't spoken in decades. His few living relatives having been out of touch which left only his partner Nate. Unfortunately, since by law Nate and Jacob weren't married [or next of kin], Jacob died alone in a hospital bed while Nate had to wait in the waiting room. 

 


Yes, you heard that correctly. Nate was sipping cold vending machine coffee in the waiting room while his partner of 27 years passed behind hospital room doors. No one was holding Jacobs hand, Nate didn't really get to say good bye. It only gets worse from here. Since Nate didn't have the best credit, their house was in Jacobs name and the cars were in Nate's name. Which means, you guessed it. After loosing his life partner  he was also ordered to leave his home. Anything that was considered Jacob's, went to his estranged family in Idaho. Since they were not married, Nate was not entitled to any of his life insurance policy or social security survivor benefits. 

So now Nate, without his partner; after losing his home and a significant portion of his house hold income had to start over at 56.

What do you say to someone in this situation? What do you say? Sorry? I'm sorry your partner passed so unexpectedly. I'm sorry that you weren't able to spend the last moments with them? I'm sorry that you aren't protected?

No amount of 'I'm Sorry' would help Nate. What would have helped Nate, would have been the ability to say good by to his partner, the ability to plan Jacobs funeral, the protection of his rights. That would have fixed it. 
----------------------------------------------------------------


Its too late to help Nate and Jacob. However, I ask that each of you strongly consider voting today and supporting Question 6. Gender equality has come a few short steps since Jacobs passing but not far enough. There are now a few small safe gaurds protecting these couples but there is still so far to go. It is up to us to stand up and support people like Nate, to help fight for their basic human rights. 

 
My mother and youngest brother

   On a more personal note; my hope is that one day I will wear a bridesmaid dress, walk down the aisle and toast my brilliant younger brother and his future husband. My hope is that when that day comes, he will have the exact same rights, protections and security that I currently have with my husband. Marriage is a very sacred thing and I strongly believe that this is a right we should afford to everyone. This cause hits very close to home for me and my family. Please use your right to vote to help others have the same rights. 

 


Defend Marriage Equality, Vote for Question 6.

item.title: Alison Harper Style//Bridesmaid's Gifts
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
Photo: Michelle Lindsey Photography


   What do you get your closest gal pals? The ones who've helped you glue 200 little ribbons onto little mini jar favors. The ladies who helped plan the most memorable bachelorette party. [-They even remember the sash]. The girls who bought the dress, the shoes, the plane ticket. The ladies who listen for months while you rattled on about linens, registries and your mother in law. I think the bridesmaids deserve a little more credit. 

    Their role starts long before that sweet beautiful walk down the aisle. I think they deserve a thoughtful, lovely, little treat for still being your friend after that one bridezilla moment. Here are some ideas. 

 
I love these personalized clutches. They can match their dress and they can use them again! They can be found in girlbyAileen Shop on etsy. You can even write a little message to them on the tag!


 
Apparently personalizing is all the rage. These little tumblers are so cute. The nice part, you can make the dresses your color and add their name! These can be found in GetItPersonalized shop on etsy.



 
I've seen similar shirts. I think they are a fabulous idea. Better yet, these have a lace razor back. Super adorable. They can be found in BrideBikini Shop on Etsy.



 
Like an adult version of the tumbler cups these champagne glasses can also be personalized with their name and dress color. Perfect for those morning of toasts! They can be found on WaterfallDesigns Etsy shop. One of our super classy brides, Mariel gave them to her ladies. 
 
Photo by Marcella Treybig Photography



 
Jewelry is always a great go to for bridesmaids. There are tons of options. I guess if we are sticking to the 'personalizing' trend this is a great option.  I just love the quote! These can be found on OtisBWeddings etsy shop. 


 
If your friends are at all like my friends these flasks would be a hit. Seriously. A hit. I'll just leave it at that. You can find these super classy flasks at EmilysEmporium1. Bonus, you can get matching groomsmen gifts!


 
Photo: Rachel Foster Photography

Out of all of these things. The most thoughtful and personal gifts would be the treat of a little pampering. [I had to say it] We are experts at making people feel beautiful, so the sweetest gift of all is a morning of papering. Make your girls feel gorgeous, treat them to a service. 

xo, 
Alison

item.title: Personal//1 Year
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
It was a busy crazy Saturday. One of the last days of our season with more than 7 weddings. I was exhausted. I carried my tired little tail up the two flights of steps into our brand new condo. I was so tired I didn't even notice the trail of little pine needles crunching under my boots. I opened the door with a sigh and what to my wondering eyes should appear?


A Fiance smiling proudly next to a naked, 5 foot Douglas fir. 


I slammed the door -crying and locked myself in the bathroom. In this moment, I was so so very upset. Doesn't he know that this was supposed to be our first Christmas tree? We were supposed to bundle up in sweaters. Rubbing our gloves together we were supposed to pace the safeway parking lot, examining each tree carefully. We were supposed to decide together which tree was not too tall, not too fat. We. We were supposed to tie it to the roof, wrestle it up the stairs. We were supposed to set it up together. I would stand back with my hot chocolate and watch him put it in the stand, telling him to move it left then right. Together. We were supposed to do this together. 

Dashed. All of it. Our Christmas card, moment. I know this sounds dramatic. I'm not arguing that, besides -I was exhausted. It was just that in my family, it was a tradition. To pick it out and set it up together. So I cried. He knocked on the bathroom door, confused. 

I finally let him in and told him. We fought. Not a crazy fight, a confused fight. Neither of us understood each other. Eventually we decorated our poor lonely tree. 

I look back at that moment and I relish in it. That beautiful, pivotal moment. It was one of those fights that only new couples have. I didn't realize that in his family the man went out in the cold and picked the sturdiest, fullest tree on the lot. He strapped it to his roof carried it home like a proud hunter. The ladies 'oooed' and 'awwed' sipping their hot chocolate while the men labored during set up. I didn't know that. -I just didn't know that. 

I cried and ruined his proud manly moment. I didn't know. It was one of those things that you learn about someone after you live with them for a while. We were new. We were new at all of this. We were new with each other. 


 


It has been about a year since that argument and it has been a interesting ride. I am not sure why I am sharing this. I just know now that this is normal. I didn't know then that this was normal. We're going to fight, we're going to have moments. 

This is being married. 


We tried it our own way this year. He picked out the tree, brought it home and I helped him set it up. Then we both admired our gorgeous full tree. It wasn't glamorous. It didn't look like a holiday card but we did it our own way.
 It was perfect. 

xo, 
Alison

item.title: Alison Harper Style//Clients For The Win
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
I've been seeing all of these other, cooler blogs doing the whole "end of the year" blog. Where they recap their over all wedding season. Jumping on that bandwagon I started looking through our photos when I realized, I should just show people how awesome our clients are instead. 

So I now present, proof that we have the most awesome clients.
XO, 
Alison 



--------

 

Meet Lauren and Adam. They were married at the very beautiful Antrim 1844 back in May. During Lauren's outdoor ceremony she was surrounded by a beautiful baby's breath hoopa and her huge beautiful family. Her reception was filled with silvers, purples, a candy bar and MORE COWBELL. 



 
Thank you to Timmester Photography for these awesome images!


--------

 

Meet Megan, she and her hubby Chris were married at the Le Meridien back in March. Their roof top ceremony was like a pinterest board come true. It was a circle ceremony, she had graffiti high heels,  tons of bling and they had their formals on some pretty serious DC Monuments. Besides all of that, what helped her make my list of awesome awesome clients was this photo: 

 
Thank you Thank you Andrew Morrell Photography


--------

 

Meet Alison. Meet Lenny, he is checking out his smoking soon to be wife. Alison doesn't know this, but I secretly adore her. Not only do we share names but she has amazing taste. Alison and Lenny celebrated their DC wedding at two classic DC spots, the Mayflower Hotel and the Daughters of the American Revolution Constitution Hall. They were surrounded by a loving excited family, beautiful soft flowers and apparently some bangin' music. Please see how Alison drops it like its hot and makes my list of awesome clients. 

 
Meredith Hanafi Photography is responsible for capturing this much awesome. 


--------


 

Meet Andrea & Peter. They had an exciting Mexican inspired wedding at the Lodge at Little Seneca Creek back in May. There were bright colors, traditional dresses and some really sweet vows exchanged. I secretly never forget couples that add that little extra flair to their wedding. I just know that the two of them are going to have a really fun life together. I mean, they had a pinata at their wedding. Come on. 

 
Thank you ZA Designz for the lovely photos! 

--------


 

Meet Meghann & Justin. They had a classic Catholic Baltimore ceremony. The reception was at the beautiful Hyatt -all decked out. I really should just let these two photos speak for themselves. Cause you know what I would say. -Badass.
 
 
 
Thank you to L and M Hewit Photography for the images!

item.title: Real Wedding//Amy & Will
item.dc:creator: alisonharperco2013
item.content:encoded:
These people know how to throw a wedding. A little while back, we celebrated Amy's wedding. First the tea ceremony, then the second ceremony and then the reception. Well, we didn't really celebrate it like they did. I mean their celebration is more like champagne, delicious cake and dancing. Our celebrating involves curling irons, bobby pins and blush. I mean, tomato-tommaaatoo, right? -Right. Amy and Will had a beautiful, classic Baltimore wedding. The Peabody Library is such an elegant venue, her dress -I could die. I even love the bridesmaid socks. Okay, enough talking. I want to share these lovely images with you. Special thank you for sharing, you should check out, 

Sincereli Photography

They are pretty good at what they do. 
xo,
 Alison
